Good day, and welcome to the Transocean's Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference. Today's conference is being recorded.
At this time, I would like to attend I would like to turn the conference over to Mr. Brad Alexander. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Transocean Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Eric. Welcome to Transocean's Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. A copy of the press release covering our financial results, along with supporting statements and schedules, including reconciliations and disclosures regarding non-GAAP
componenttext:
Thank you, Eric. Welcome to Transocean's Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. A copy of the press release covering our financial results, along with supporting statements and schedules, including reconciliations and disclosures regarding non-GAAP financial measures, are posted on the company's website at deepwater.com.
Joining me on this morning's call are Jeremy Thigpen, President and Chief Executive Officer; Mark Mey, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and Terry Bonno, Senior Vice President, Marketing. During the course of this call, participants may make certain forward-looking statements regarding various matters related to our business and company that are not historical facts. Such statements are based upon the current expectations and certain assumptions of management and are, therefore, subject to certain risks and uncertainties. Many factors could cause actual results to differ materially. Please refer to our SEC filings for more information regarding our forward-looking statements, including the risks and uncertainties that could impact our future results. Also, please note that the company undertakes no duty to update or revise forward-looking statements. [Operator Instructions]
Thank you very much. I'll now turn the call over to Jeremy Thigpen

headline: Transocean Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Brad, and a warm welcome to our employees, customers, investors and analysts participating in today's call. Our performance in the fourth quarter were strong across the board as we reported adjusted net income of $650 million or $1.68 per dilut
componenttext:
Thank you, Brad, and a warm welcome to our employees, customers, investors and analysts participating in today's call. Our performance in the fourth quarter were strong across the board as we reported adjusted net income of $650 million or $1.68 per diluted share. On $1.9 billion of revenues. For the full year, our adjusted net income was $1.7 billion or $4.74 per diluted share on $7.4 billion in revenue.
During the quarter, our strong revenue efficiency, our intense focus and our cost structure and the proceeds from some early contract terminations resulted in an operating margin, including G&A, of approximately 54%. For the full year, excluding the impact of the Macondo settlement, our adjusted operating margin was 47%. These results reflect the unwavering commitment of the entire Transocean team to delivering the best operational performance in the industry. So to those Transocean employees who may be listening to today's call, thank you for your continued focus and dedication throughout what a very challenging year for our industry.
In addition to delivering strong financial results, I'm pleased report that Transocean for the reduced its total recordable incident rate during the quarter, while simultaneously including uptime and revenue efficiency which was an impressive 95.9% for the fourth quarter. For the full year 2015, we produced the lowest annual total recordable incident rate and the company's history, while delivering our highest annual average revenue efficiency of 96%, which further solidifies our position that safety and efficiency go hand-in-hand. Once again, I would like to recognize and thank our crews and our shore base personnel for their continued commitment to both protecting each other and the environment in which we operate and maximizing uptime for our customers.
I would also like to take a moment to recognize our marketing and contract teams. Despite the extremely challenging market conditions, by leveraging our excellent operational performance and introducing some new commercial models and alternative solutions for our customers, we added a number of contracts to our backlog late in the fourth quarter. While most of the awards were short duration, we were pleased to secure some longer-term arrangements in Canada, India and the North Sea. Terry will soon provide more detail regarding each of these pictures.
Needless today, we are pleased for the company's performance in the fourth quarter and throughout the full year 2015. However, we recognize that there is more to be done. As we move through 2016, we will further define and capitalize on opportunities to reduce our incident rate and improve our uptime performance. We will also take additional action streamline and drive efficiencies into our organization and to our processes and we will continue to high-grade our fleet.
In an effort to further improve our safety and operational performance in 2016, we are investing time and resources into enhancing our tools, procedures and training programs. Once completed and rolled out company-wide, we will be at an even stronger position to drive discipline and consistency of performance across our entire fleet.
While investing in new tools and training programs to drive safety and performance improvements, we are also evaluating our organization and our internal processes and identifying opportunities to optimize each. As discussed in some detail last quarter, we are reorganizing internally. Among other things, we have significantly reduced the layers between senior management and the RIG. As a result, our organization has become flatter and our operational efficiency has improved materially. This organizational change has also resulted in a majority of our support functions that's being centralized in Houston with the downsizing or outright elimination of hub offices on the world. These changes began in late 2015 and should be fully implemented by the end of the second quarter of 2016, which will result in additional cost savings as we've progressed through the year.
In addition to improving the efficiency of our structure, you will remember from the last call that we are also defining and implementing innovative approaches to enhance our maintenance activities and to reduce a bit time and cost required to stack a rig. Well, I'm pleased ro report that we are now realizing the benefit of these approaches and as you will here in Georgia's guidance, we expect recognize for their cost reductions in both areas has removed through the year.
And finally, since we remain confident in the ultimate recovery of commodity prices and the offshore industry, we are continuing to high-grade our fleet. The Deepwater Thalassa, the first of 4 new build ultra-deepwater drillships that will operate for Shell on tendered contract went on dayrate in early February in the Gulf of Mexico. The second new you build drillship for Shell, the Deepwater Pontus, is expected to arrive in Gulf of Mexico in several weeks where it will begin its contract in Shell for the second quarter.
Lastly, the Deepwater Conqueror, which is a 5-year contract with Chevron, is on schedule and due to  be delivered later this year.
While we are certainly excited about these additions to our fleet and the future revenue and earnings that they represent, we also recognize the need to continually revaluate the composition, capability and marketability of individual rigs within our fleet.
Consistent with our fleet renewal strategy, during the quarter, we classified 2 additional rigs, the Deepwater Navigator, and the GSF Rig Grand Banks was held for sale. For those keeping score, since the start of the downturn, we are now 24 floaters, either scrapped or held for sale. As we move forward, we will continue to objectively evaluate both our rigs coming off a contract as well as our currently stacked rigs to quickly determine whether or not each individual assets still supports our long-term asset strategy.
Before I hand the call over to Mark, he will provide you with additional comment on the company's financial performance and then Terry, who will provide an update on the market. I would just like to take a moment to stress that the Deepwater floater market is the most challenging it's ever been. To overcome this challenge, we will continue with approach of managing those things within our control, such as continue to improve on safety and operational performance, streamlining the business and our processes and high-grading our fleet and our crews. Our customers needs superior execution and our ability to distinguish Transocean and these area is what will keep our rigs working and allow us to build our reputation as the industry's preferred contract driller.
With our $15.5 billion backlog, of which is approximately 89% this with investment-grade companies and our more than $5 billion of liquidity, we have the platform we need to imagine this downturn in a much stronger leadership position, and I have every confidence that we will.
With that, let me hand it over to Mark.

headline: Transocean Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jeremy, and good day, to all. As we provided expensive detail in the fourth quarter results in our and introduce, well, let me briefly touch on quarter's financial performance during this call. I will focus instead of providing you with an upda
componenttext:
Thank you, Jeremy, and good day, to all. As we provided expensive detail in the fourth quarter results in our and introduce, well, let me briefly touch on quarter's financial performance during this call. I will focus instead of providing you with an update to our 2016 guidance and discuss our balance sheet and liquidity position.
For the fourth quarter, 2015, we reported net income attributable to controlling interest of $611 million or $1.66 per diluted share. These results included $4 million or $0.02 per share in net attributable items that are detailed in our press release. Excluding these items, adjusted net income was $615 million were $1.68 per diluted share.
Total revenue for the fourth quarter of 2015 increased by $243 million sequentially to $1.85 billion. Other revenue increased $356 million due to the early terminations of [indiscernible] Pioneer, Discovery Americas and Rig 714. Contract drilling revenue decreased $130 million due to reduced activity and rig retirement, partially offset by higher ultra-deepwater revenue efficiency and higher demobilization revenue. The demobilization revenue during the period was associated with the lump sum revenue recognized in the product and the completion of the trailer to contract in December.
We recognized approximately 80% of the product by reduce lump sum payment as revenue in 2015. The remaining portion associated with the demobilization of the rig would like to be recognized as contract drilling revenue in 2016.
Fourth quarter fleet utilization was 60%, down from 70% in the prior quarter. This is also this 632 operating days mainly attributable to fewer recontracting opportunities for a harsh environment and mid-water Semites. As Jeremy mentioned, we achieved either quarter of outstanding revenue efficiency of 95.9% with will year 2015 averaging 96%. So that's 2 conservative use of efficiency at or above 95%.
And so for our 2016, the uptime performance for our rigs remains strong. This is attributable to the exceptional focus and execution for operational and technical teams worldwide.
Fourth quarter operating and maintenance expense decreased by $86 million sequentially to $794 million. Although within our full year guidance, fourth quarter O&M was slightly higher than the forecasted due to unplanned demobilization costs, which will offset by increased revenue just discussed. The quarter was also impacted by lower activity due to 632 operating days during the quarter and the company's actions to reduce onshore and offshore process. Janne expenses decreased sequentially by $30 million to $58 million. As discussed during last quarter's call, fourth quarter G&A include restructuring costs associated with employee severance payments and office these termination charges. Operating margin, including G&A expense, was approximately 54% in the quarter, driven higher by the impact of early contract terminations included in other revenue mentioned above. Adjusted for this additional revenue, our operating margins were approximately 43% and in line with the prior quarter.
The fourth quarter annual effective tax rate was 15.1%, or 7.5% in the prior quarter. The increase was due largely to changes in adjusted pretax income, currency exchange rate and the impact of jurisdictional and operational structure changes in certain rigs implemented this quarter.
The annual effective tax rate for 2015 were 16.4%, low guided you to largely revenue associated with contract terminations during the fourth quarter. We ended the quarter with $2.34 billion in cash and cash equivalents. This includes cash from operations of $960 million. Capital expenditures totaled $665 million related to a second delivery repeat order produce and other new book CapEx payments during the quarter.
During the fourth quarter, we opportunistically repurchased $207 million of debt at a cost of $196 million, bringing our total 2015 repurchases of $503 million, at a cost of $473 million. About 85% of the early debt repurchases were mid-dated maturities. Cash interest for the repurchases amounted to approximately $84 million over the remaining term. The vast majority of which benefit cash flows over the next 3 years. As part of the organizational streamline encouraging underway, we announced our intention to Swiss stock exchange. The last days March 30. The companyshares will continue to be traded from a in the New York Stock Exchange. I will now provide an update on our financial expectations 2016, which reflect our confidence and continued strong uptime performance and more efficient cost structure. I will also update our liquidity's expectations through 2017.
Our 2016 revenue efficiency guidance remains at 95%. Other revenue for 2016 were expected to be between $60 million and $70 million, this includes customer reimbursables, but excludes $200 million of early termination fee as a shared with the contract insulations recognized to date in 2016.
As we compute our annual budgeting process, we could not update our preliminary cost guidance provided during the previous earnings call. We expect full year upgrading and maintenance expense to range between $2.2 billion and $2.5 billion. This is about of percent lower than hourly expectations due to fewer forecast operating days associated with early part of terminations and some of our rigs and limited opportunities for re-contracting some of these assets in 2016.
The updated 2016 O&M guidance is also above 40% lower on an adjusted 2015 O&M costs. Of this reduction, approximately 70% is associated with reduced activity and lower ultra-deepwater cost and about 10% from lower out-of-service costs.
The remaining 2016 Pontus cost decrease is related to more streamlined operating, overheads support models. As we discussed, last quarter, we're implementing structural changes to organization which will improve operating margin, earnings and related cash flow. These cost reductions are largely offset by reactivation of the Henry Goodrich, which will commence his 2-year contract with husky in the second quarter 2016. The contract commencement of the 3 -- of our 3 new build ultra-deepwater drillship Deepwater Thalassa, which Jeremy mentioned, as well as the Deepwater Pontus and Deepwater Conqueror in second and third quarters, respectively.
Our G&A expense for 2016 is full expected to be approximately $155 million. The reduced expense applications are due mainly to smaller corporate structures and related office closures. This guidance excludes approximately $5 million in restructuring costs. We expect annual depreciation expense 2016 to the between $875 million and $925 million. Full year 2016 net interest expense is expected to be between $365 million and $380 million. The year-over-year decrease is mainly associated with the increased levels of capitalized interest due largely to the changes in the construction and risk balances.
Net interest expense includes capitalized interest and interest income of $175 million and $10 million, respectively. Full year 2016 annual effective tax rate from continuing operations is expected to be between 20% and 32%. The increase is a result of the lower level of pretax income. Capital expenditures for 2016 are expected to be approximately $1.4 billion, excluding $1.15 billion of Deepwater Conqueror, Deepwater Champion and Deepwater Poseidon and $180 million for capitalized interest. Maintenance CapEx is estimated to be approximately $100 million. This reduced level of maintenance capital expenditures is it with our estimate for a limited number out of service days.
Turning now to our cash position. We have made the following assumptions and updated liquidity forecast through 2017. This include revenue efficiency of 95%; a limited number of new contract awards that resumes at or near cash price given; existing drilling contracts in mining tax and working capital release of approximately $600 million in total for the years 2016, 2017.
Related to 2017, we expect total Capex of approximately $600 million. This includes $175 million in new build payment, $150 million in capitalized interest and approximately $250 million in maintenance CapEx.
This maintenance CapEx provides exclusive maintenance of rigs for potential future contract rowers. Based upon our current at December 31, 2017, remains in the range $4 billion to $5 billion. It's the vast majority of the contract termination payments received, approximate forecasted operating cash flow under this contract. An exception to the recent cancellation of the DP 1 contract, unfortunately, we will not receive a termination payment, the customer has the contractual option to cancel the convenience. We estimated, this contract installation will reduce cash flow by approximately $56 million and 2016 and 2017. Jeremy will discuss this in more detail during his prepared comment. After Jason continues to improve our $3 billion undrawn revolving credit facility that is available to us for mid-2019.
To conclude, we are very pleased with our operational results including exceptional revenue business and improvements in our cost structure. This we become an ideal organization, we are doing more with more with Eclairs, but the quality of our service remain high. We are not satisfied, however, and we'll continue to challenge [indiscernible] mentioned, strive to for even greater performance to out-mitigate the reduced fleet utilization.
This concludes my prepared comments. I will now turn the call over to Terry. Terry?

headline: Transocean Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mark, and good day, to everyone. To simply say the offshore drilling market continues to be challenging is an understatement. Yet in the fourth quarter, our teams, onshore and offshore, fired on all cylinders to deliver multiple contracts when opp
componenttext:
Thanks, Mark, and good day, to everyone. To simply say the offshore drilling market continues to be challenging is an understatement. Yet in the fourth quarter, our teams, onshore and offshore, fired on all cylinders to deliver multiple contracts when opportunities were scarce. But oil prices recently fallen as low as the mid-20s and continuing to harbor around $30 a barrel, contract terminations that began accelerating in December has continued. Fortunately, because of our strong contract and relationships, we do not have other contract in our backlog that permit uncompensated cancellation for convenience like the termination we recently announced related to the global NFA development driller 1. I will reiterate what I said in our last earnings call, although demand is limited, we continue to fight for every opportunity in this highly competitive market. As a testament to our safety and operational performance and the creativity and tenacity of our marketing team, we've added $378 million of contract backlog since the last earnings call, bringing our total 2015 to $763 million. We have contracted to reactivate the Henry Goodrich Canada for 2 years; secure contracts to retun the RIG 140 in India and the hume to work. We have also extended the contract for the Jack Bates in Australia and rewarded over 80 days for the caging express in the Ivory Coast. While signing new contracts for active rigs, the [indiscernible] has 704 in U.K. and the Transocean Arctic in Norway. Our global footprint is vast and our ability to compete for work with our diverse fleet of rigs while capitalizing on our operational excellence is strong. As evidenced of our competitive positioning, I am especially pleased to report that since issuing our Fleet Status Report earlier this month, we were awarded a 6-month contract for the KG2 with undisclosed operator and we expect to come from a several additional contracts in the near term. However, due to the negotiations not yet being final and the competitiveness of the current market, we will refrain from commenting specifically on these today.
Our backlog as of February 11, was $15.5 billion dollars, the strongest in the industry comprising primarily of IOC's with strong balance sheet. This balance sheet provides for solid cash flow generation with 78% of revenues contracted with the IOC's, 15% contracted with independent and 7% contracted with that NOC. Turning to the current market. Charging conditions are not likely to continue into 2017. Negatively impacting both utilization and day rates while limiting rig contracting opportunities for all classes of rigs. Ultra-depwater rigs for newer your cash operating cost breakeven in most areas, and marketing utilization. And market utilizations, down 79%, between 27 rigs idled and 21 coal stacks. To provided a little more perspective on the competitiveness of the market, that longest term contracting opportunity currently in the Indian market, has attracted 14 rigs from 10 different competitors. The associated rig classes range for fourth 6th generation units with very competitive pricing expected.
Deepwater market utilization is down to 70% with only 3 fixtures year-to-date being recorded. This is coming off a total of 10 fixtures in '15, primarily, in Australia and Asia. There are currently 10 idle and 11 cold stacked Deepwater rigs.
In India, the second ONG CT are tender attracted 8 rigs from 7 different contractors ranging from second to fourth generation rigs. Submitting on these opportunities will also be very competitive. Mid warning utilization is at 69% with 3 fixtures contracted year-to-date for U.K. and Norway. This adds to a total of 19 fixtures in 2015. Currently, there are 16 idle midwater rigs in the 15 units coal stacked. There are 47 coal stacked units plus 48 floaters that are retired of being held for sale. The Transocean accounting for over 40% of the combined total. We expect these numbers to continue to increase with the overcapacity of supply and near term lack of demand, forcing the retirement of more asset. The difficult macro conditions are also resulting in more customers terminating contracts early. This further exacerbate the oversupply floater market and is a direct result of customers curtailing part of their offshore programs to preserve liquidity. Despite the severity of the downturn, there are some emerging opportunities we are discussing with customers. Some are taking the countercyclical approach, a contracting local solutions with their programs later in '16 and into ''17, realized the benefit of the reduced day rates to their overall project economics.
The jackup market continues to deteriorate as a result of increased market oversupply. This is also being exacerbated by a few rigs being cold stacked for scrap and the newbuild deliveries continue unabated. Utilization and day rates are rapidly declining. Marketed utilization is approximately 72%, but 119 rigs currently warm stacked in 65 coal stacked. With a relatively low cost associated with stacking your jackup breaks, scrapping activity is expected to be slower. Unlike the floater market, NOCs are leveraging the local market dominant and renegotiated day rates lower based on the decline; in oil prices. Industry delays that new build deliveries for both ultra-deepwater asset and jack-ups provides the medium-term relief in the excess rigs apply but continued industry attrition and stacking will contribute the most to permanently correcting the global oversupply situation. Overall, our customers are focused on reducing costs but remain keenly focused on improving operational and safety performance. Additionally, with the duration of this downturn increasing, balance sheets strength and drilling contractors in their long-term viability are becoming key criteria for our operators. With our strong liquidity come a industry-leading backlog, diverse fleet and excellent safety and operational track record, we are positioning Transocean to increase our market leading position. As such, we are keenly focused on extending both our customer and stakeholder expectations.
This concludes my overview of the market. So I will turn it over to Brad.

So until we get something completed, we're not going to comment further on this, but you can be sure that we are focused on [indiscernible] in the most effective way to be able to raise additional financial, to be able to increase our buff liquidity as we navigate this downturn.

componenttextpreview: Sure. I would say that we remain committed to high-grading our fleet, certainly, and we would certainly, like to lead the consolidation of the market, however, we have 3 very important criteria that have to be met in that process. One is asset quality. Tw
componenttext: Sure. I would say that we remain committed to high-grading our fleet, certainly, and we would certainly, like to lead the consolidation of the market, however, we have 3 very important criteria that have to be met in that process. One is asset quality. Two, would be near-term liquidity, and three would be a reasonable and realistic valuation and so aligning those 3 is a bit challenging but we're continuing to pursue opportunities, and still believe that ultimately, we will leave this consolidation effort.

componenttext: Thanks, James. I'll just speak generally. The primary tweak that we have introduced is really aligning with the expectations of our customers around performance. And the weed -- so we actually put a bit a spin on the game, if you will, and work on them with the dayrate and then build upside based on our performance. and today, our customers have expanded actually well and our performance has been very solid. So overall, we're earning above market rates on most of these agreements. So for us, we think it is a win-win. It's better aligned with our customers around performance and ultimately, they're guaranteed dayrate are below our market but over overall day rate is actually above market. So all in, both parties seems to be satisfied with the approach so far.

We don't have any other contract that don't provide for compensation and we're just fighting together to keep the rigs working.

I remember in certain times in the past, there had been discussion that these operators don't want to take a cap rate and risk safety or performance around that. But now, with so many different assets available to the market, has there been add change in the customer dynamic? Are they more focused on getting the lowest price now irrespective of the perspective safety or operational dynamics?

headline: Transocean Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think and a customer whatever sacrifice safety on any operational dynamic. They have to trust who they're going to work with. But certainly, in order to get their project off launchpad, they're going to fight for the lowest price. And they're gett
componenttext: I don't think and a customer whatever sacrifice safety on any operational dynamic. They have to trust who they're going to work with. But certainly, in order to get their project off launchpad, they're going to fight for the lowest price. And they're getting it as you say, because, Kurt, the availability is there, they are good operators that can start sake do this work. But I think the dynamic has changed as they looking for contract drillers who are going to be viable because if you know from their perspective, they can't sacrifice the safety and if they're going to contract with someone that may be cutting their maintenance or something like that, not that I'm saying it would, then I think they got a question, I think there are taking that into consideration. I think that's the difference.

headline: Transocean Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And my follow-up question, for Jeremy, you mentioned the consolidation in the different criteria around the prospects for doing any kind a deal and the discipline around that. It's always hard it seems in this business to get deals done at th
componenttext: Okay, great. And my follow-up question, for Jeremy, you mentioned the consolidation in the different criteria around the prospects for doing any kind a deal and the discipline around that. It's always hard it seems in this business to get deals done at the very tropical market like we were in right now, and then it becomes even more difficult to go to your discounted cash flow analysis because somebody you want to consolidate with have a view the rig is going to work 90% of the time and you may have a different view on that. So you see that there has been a narrowing, at all, of the gap on the outlook to bid ask for any of the dynamic that might be the consolidation in the industry?

headline: Transocean Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I don't know that there been a narrowing that's early [indiscernible], Kurt, and I appreciate your comment about the throughout. I'm not sure that everybody knows we're at that point yet. I would say that, that people are definitely becoming sober ab
componenttext: Yes. I don't know that there been a narrowing that's early [indiscernible], Kurt, and I appreciate your comment about the throughout. I'm not sure that everybody knows we're at that point yet. I would say that, that people are definitely becoming sober about the current reality and as we've stated, and I think our competitors have stated, I don't think anybody expect 2016 to get any better and most don't believe that 2017 is going to be real pretty. And so I think as we continue to work through the rest of 2016, you could see that, that bid has come together and you could see more opportunities out there for some consolidation.

headline: Transocean Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, there has been a bit of publicity on that, unnoted. I will say, we have obviously, we're been in conversation with various equipment providers. And I don't know if it's the same model that DE, Adidas, Diamond and GE entered into, but My guess is they
componenttext: Yes, there has been a bit of publicity on that, unnoted. I will say, we have obviously, we're been in conversation with various equipment providers. And I don't know if it's the same model that DE, Adidas, Diamond and GE entered into, but My guess is they're probably fairly similar. For us, we see some positives and some negative. On the positive side, there's, obviously, an in near term liquidity for the drilling contractor the any impact on near-term liquidity for the drilling contractor, which is good. And we also think it's positive to align critical equipment providers with drilling contractors with, ultimately the operators to improve up their performance. Those are 2 good things and thing's that we'd certainly considered. For us, there appeared to be 2 challenges. One is, while we recognize the benefit of near-term liquidity when you fell the BOP and the associated spares, the ongoing cost from the equipment provider, the healthcare contracted, if you will, is a bit prohibitive. And so that's a concern for us. And the other piece of it, I mean, well, if you think about that cost of the contract, it really increases your total cost to ownership. So while you get the benefit near-term, the total cost of ownership longer term, becomes a bit of a challenge for us. The other thing for us is we have been unbelievably successful in improving our uptime performance for all subsidy-related equipment. And so when you at the associated with service agreements plus we don't see a lot of incremental opportunity of improvement that this could potentially bring, for. For us, we're not quite sure that model works as we understand it today. Having said that, we are working with our equipment providers to look at other ways to go line differnet model that may make sense for more of us and also improve our uptime performance on our equipment. So it's not the net we're pursuing, we're talking to divider, my guess is the model would a different than what was announced by diamond, but it is something we're looking at.

componenttext: I think internally, it's around business simplification. This is an organization that have multiple acquisitions over these. Maybe not all of them were fully integrated and we've been in the market where everything has been up into the right for a number of years. And in the market like that, sometimes you build in infrastructure, you build in process, as if maybe you don't necessarily need and especially as you're shrinking to a much smaller business that you were a few years ago. And so we just take a fresh look at our entire infrastructure, all our positions, all of all roles, all of our processes to try and simplify and drive waste and cost side of our business. So it is full-scale across the board.

componenttext: Well, Darren, I think it's pretty obvious that liquidity over the near term, near term, meaning next 3 to 5 years is at the utmost importance to us. If you look at what we have done today, about 10% of the funds we've used to repurchase debt has been focused on debt outside of that near-term liquidity window. So, obviously, that in the case, our most important focuses on maintaining and increasing liquidity, but we will opportunistically take a look at buying some of the heavy discounted debt securities that we feel best in price in the market.

componenttext: Thanks, Robin, Yes. I wouldn't go further than that, I'll give it to you too, as little as 19 as well. As you're probably read in our 10-K, we have 1 financial problem in our revolver, that's a debt-to-cap covenant of 60%. We were currently stopped 40% on that and we have to include significant addition or reductions in our capital base or increases in our debt pretty close to that level. So we have unlimited access to that revolver through the middle of '19, where it matures and specifically, focused on our internal projections and models. So we don't have the 3 or 4 different financial public certificates find in these revolvers because this was negotiated during the time when the company was still investment grade.

componenttext: Hi, Waqar, I think what the customers are saying, I just need to see some stability. componenttext: Well, I think you need to look at what our customers are telling us, and a lot of things that we are seeing now is that they are resetting their cost basis. I think that -- there was a report that came out about Norway, and they were saying, they had take significant cost out of their structures. And now $35 a barrel in Norway, if you can imagine, doesn't look so bad. So I think it's case-by-case, customer by customer in area by area and that's a really difficult thing to nail exactly what is right because it is still dependent on the area of operations and other constraints involved with that but again, I think it's just some confidence and some stability.

Good day, and welcome to the Transocean's Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference. Today's conference is being recorded.
At this time, I'd like to put the conference over to Mr. Brad Alexander. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Transocean Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Eric. Welcome to Transocean's Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. A copy of the press release covering our financial results, along with supporting statements and schedules, including reconciliations and disclosures regarding non-GAAP
componenttext:
Thank you, Eric. Welcome to Transocean's Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. A copy of the press release covering our financial results, along with supporting statements and schedules, including reconciliations and disclosures regarding non-GAAP financial measures, are posted on the company's website at deepwater.com.
Joining me on this morning's call are Jeremy Thigpen, President and Chief Executive Officer; Mark Mey, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and Terry Bonno, Senior Vice President, Marketing.
During the course of this call, participants may make certain forward-looking statements regarding various matters related to our business and company that are not historical facts. Such statements are based upon the current expectations and certain assumptions of management and are, therefore, subject to certain risks and uncertainties. Many factors could cause actual results to differ materially. Please refer to our SEC filings for more information regarding our forward-looking statements, including the risks and uncertainties that could impact our future results. Also, please note that the company undertakes no duty to update or revise forward-looking statements.
[Operator Instructions]
Thank you very much. I'll now turn the call over to Jeremy Thigpen.

headline: Transocean Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Brad, and a warm welcome to our employees, customers, investors and analysts participating in today's call. Our performance in the fourth quarter was strong across the board as we reported adjusted net income of $615 million or $1.68 per dilute
componenttext:
Thank you, Brad, and a warm welcome to our employees, customers, investors and analysts participating in today's call. Our performance in the fourth quarter was strong across the board as we reported adjusted net income of $615 million or $1.68 per diluted share on $1.9 billion in revenues. For the full year, our adjusted net income was $1.7 billion or $4.74 per diluted share on $7.4 billion in revenue.
During the quarter, our strong revenue efficiency, our intense focus on our cost structure and the proceeds from some early contract terminations resulted in an operating margin, including G&A, of approximately 54%. For the full year, excluding the impact of the Macondo settlement, our adjusted operating margin was 47%.
These results reflect the unwavering commitment of the entire Transocean team to delivering the best operational performance in the industry. So to those Transocean employees who may be listening to today's call, thank you for your continued focus and dedication throughout what was a very challenging year for our industry.
In addition to delivering strong financial results, I'm pleased report that Transocean further reduced its total recordable incident rate during the quarter while simultaneously improving uptime and revenue efficiency, which was an impressive 95.9% for the fourth quarter.
For the full year of 2015, we produced the lowest annual total recordable incident rate in the company's history while delivering our highest annual average revenue efficiency of 96%, which further solidifies our position that safety and efficiency go hand in hand.
Once again, I would like to recognize and thank our crews and our shore-based personnel for their continued commitment to both protecting each other and the environments in which we operate and maximizing uptime for our customers.
I would also like to take a moment to recognize our marketing and contract teams, despite the extremely challenging market conditions. By leveraging our excellent operational performance and introducing some new commercial models and alternative solutions for our customers, we added a number of contracts to our backlog late in the fourth quarter. While most of the awards were short duration, we were pleased to secure some longer-term arrangements in Canada, India and the North Sea. Terry will soon provide more detail regarding each of these pictures.
Needless to say, we are pleased with the company's performance in the fourth quarter and throughout the full year of 2015. However, we recognize that there is more to be done. As we move through 2016, we will further define and capitalize on opportunities to reduce our incident rate and improve our uptime performance. We will also take additional actions to streamline and drive efficiencies into our organization and our processes, and we will continue to high-grade our fleet.
In an effort to further improve our safety and operational performance in 2016, we are investing time and resources into enhancing our tools, procedures and training programs. Once completed and rolled out company-wide, we will be at an even stronger position to drive procedural discipline and consistency of performance across our entire fleet.
While investing in new tools and training programs to drive safety and performance improvements, we are also reevaluating our organization and our internal processes and identifying opportunities to optimize each. As discussed in some detail last quarter, we are reorganizing internally. Among other things, we have significantly reduced the layers between senior management and the rig. As a result, our organization has become flatter and our operational efficiency has improved materially. This organizational change has also resulted in the majority of our support functions being centralized in Houston with the downsizing or outright elimination of hub offices around the world. These changes began in late 2015 and should be fully implemented by the end of the second quarter of 2016, which will result in additional cost savings as we progress through the year.
In addition to improving the efficiency of our structure, you will remember from the last call that we are also defining and implementing innovative approaches to enhance our maintenance activities and to reduce the time and cost required to stack a rig. Well, I'm pleased to report that we are now realizing the benefit of these approaches. And as you will here in Mark's guidance, we expect to recognize further cost reductions in both areas as we move through the year.
And finally, since we remain confident in the ultimate recovery of commodity prices and the offshore industry, we are continuing to high-grade our fleet. The Deepwater Thalassa, the first of 4 new-build ultra-deepwater drillships that will operate for Shell on 10-year contracts went on day rate in early February in the Gulf of Mexico. The second newbuild drillship for Shell, the Deepwater Proteus, is expected to arrive in the Gulf of Mexico in several weeks, where it will begin its contract for Shell in the second quarter.
Lastly, the Deepwater Conqueror, which is a 5-year contract with Chevron, is on schedule and due to be delivered later this year.
While we are certainly excited about these additions to our fleet and the future revenue and earnings that they represent, we also recognize the need to continually reevaluate the composition, capability and marketability of individual rigs within our fleet.
Consistent with our fleet renewal strategy, during the quarter, we classified 2 additional rigs, the Deepwater Navigator and the GSF Grand Banks, as held for sale.
For those keeping score, since the start of this downturn, we have now 24 floaters either scrapped or held for sale. As we move forward, we will continue to objectively evaluate both our rigs coming off of contracts as well as our currently stacked rigs to quickly determine whether or not each individual assets still supports our long-term asset strategy.
Before I hand the call over to Mark, who will provide you with additional comments on the company's financial performance; and then Terry, who will provide an update on the market, I would just like to take a moment to stress that the Deepwater floater market is the most challenged it has ever been. To overcome this challenge, we will continue with the approach of managing those things within our control, such as continuing to improve on safety and operational performance, streamlining the business and our processes and high-grading our fleet and our crews. Our customers need superior execution, and our ability to distinguish Transocean in these area is what will keep our rigs working and allow us to build on our reputation as the industry's preferred contract driller.
With our $15.5 billion backlog, of which approximately 89% is with investment-grade companies, and our more than $5 billion of liquidity, we have the platform that we need to emerge from this downturn in a much stronger leadership position, and I have every confidence that we will.
With that, let me hand it over to Mark.

headline: Transocean Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jeremy, and good day to all. As we provided extensive detail on the fourth quarter's results in our earnings release, I'll only briefly touch on the quarter's financial performance during this call. I will focus instead of providing you with an
componenttext:
Thank you, Jeremy, and good day to all. As we provided extensive detail on the fourth quarter's results in our earnings release, I'll only briefly touch on the quarter's financial performance during this call. I will focus instead of providing you with an update to our 2016 guidance and discuss our balance sheet and liquidity position.
For the fourth quarter 2015, we reported net income attributable to controlling interest of $611 million or $1.66 per diluted share. These results included $4 million or $0.02 per share in net unfavorable items that are detailed in our press release. Excluding these items, adjusted net income was $615 million or $1.68 per diluted share.
Total revenue for the fourth quarter of 2015 increased by $243 million sequentially to $1.85 billion. Other revenue increased $356 million due to the early terminations of the Polar Pioneer, Discoverer Americas and Sedco 714. Contract drilling revenue decreased $113 million due to reduced activity and rig retirement, partially offset by higher ultra-deepwater revenue efficiency and higher demobilization revenue. The demobilization revenue during the period was primarily associated with the lump-sum revenue recognized in the Polar Pioneer and the completion of Development Driller II contract in December.
We recognized approximately 80% of the Polar Pioneer's lump-sum payment as revenue in 2015. The remaining portion associated with the demobilization of the rig will largely be recognized as contract drilling revenue in 2016.
Fourth quarter fleet utilization was 60%, down from 70% in the prior quarter. This results in a 632 operating days mainly attributable to fewer recontracting opportunities for our harsh environment and deepwater semis. As Jeremy mentioned, we achieved another quarter of outstanding revenue efficiency of 95.9% with full year 2015 averaging 96%. So that's 2 consecutive years with revenue efficiency at or above 95%.
And so far in 2016, the uptime performance of our rigs remains strong. This is attributable to the exceptional focus and execution of our operational and technical teams worldwide.
Fourth quarter operating and maintenance expense decreased by $86 million sequentially to $794 million. Although within our full year guidance, fourth quarter O&M was slightly higher than we forecasted due to unplanned demobilization costs, which were offset by increased revenue just discussed. The quarter was also impacted by lower activity due to 632 operating days during the quarter and the company's actions to reduce onshore and offshore process.
G&A expenses increased sequentially by $13 million to $58 million. As discussed during last quarter's call, fourth quarter G&A include restructuring costs associated with employee severance payments and office lease termination charges. Operating margin, including G&A expense, was approximately 54% in the quarter, driven higher by the impact of early contract terminations included in other revenue mentioned above. Adjusted for this additional revenue, our operating margins were approximately 43% and in line with the prior quarter.
The fourth quarter annual effective tax rate was 13.1% compared with 7.5% in the prior quarter. The increase was due largely to changes in adjusted pretax income, currency exchange rates and the impact of jurisdictional and operational structure changes for certain rigs implemented last quarter.
The annual effective tax rate for 2015 was 16.4%, lower than guidance due largely to the revenue associated with contract terminations during the fourth quarter.
We ended the quarter with $2.34 billion in cash and cash equivalents. This includes cash flow from operations of $960 million.
Capital expenditures totaled $665 million related to a second delivery of the Deepwater Proteus and other newbuild CapEx payments during the quarter.
During the fourth quarter, we opportunistically repurchased $211 million of debt at a cost of $196 million, bringing our total 2015 repurchases to $503 million at a cost of $473 million. About 85% of the early debt repurchases were near-dated maturities.
Cash interest for the debt repurchases is approximately $84 million over the remaining term. The vast majority of which benefit cash flows over the next 3 years.
As part of the organizational streamlining currently underway, we recently announced our intention to delist with the Swiss Stock Exchange. The last trading day is scheduled for March 30. The company shares will continue to be listed and traded on the New York Stock Exchange.
I will now provide an update on our financial expectations for 2016, which reflect our confidence and continued strong uptime performance and more efficient cost structure. I will also update our liquidity's expectations through 2017.
Our 2016 revenue efficiency guidance remains at 95%. Other revenue for 2016 is expected to be between $60 million and $70 million. This includes customer reimbursables but excludes $200 million of early termination fees associated with the contract cancellations recognized to date in 2016.
After having completed our annual budgeting process, we can now update our preliminary cost guidance provided during the previous earnings call. We expect full year upgrading and maintenance expense to range between $2.2 billion and $2.5 billion. This level is about 12% lower than our early expectations due to fewer forecasted operating days associated with the early contract terminations in some of our rigs and limited opportunities for recontracting some of these assets in 2016.
The updated 2016 O&M guidance is also about 40% lower from the adjusted 2015 O&M costs. Of this reduction, approximately 70% is associated with reduced activity and lower ultra-deepwater cold stacking costs and about 10% from lower out-of-service costs.
The remaining 2016 O&M cost decrease is related to more streamlined operating and overhead support models. As we discussed, last quarter, we're implementing structural changes to our organization which will improve operating margins, earnings and related cash flow. These cost reductions are partially offset by the reactivation of the Henry Goodrich, which will commence its 2-year contract with Husky in the second quarter of 2016. The contract commencement of the 3 -- for our 3 newbuild ultra-deepwater drillship, the Deepwater Thalassa, which Jeremy mentioned, as well as the Deepwater Proteus and Deepwater Conqueror, in the second and fourth quarters, respectively.
Our G&A expense for 2016 is still expected to be approximately $155 million. The reduced expense expectations are due mainly to our smaller corporate structure and related office closures. This guidance excludes approximately $5 million in restructuring costs.
We expect annual depreciation expense in 2016 to between $875 million and $925 million. Full year 2016 net interest expense is expected to be between $365 million and $380 million. The year-over-year decrease is mainly associated with the increased levels of capitalized interest due largely to the changes in the construction progress balances.
Net interest expense includes capitalized interest and interest income of $175 million and $10 million, respectively.
Full year 2016 annual effective tax rate from continuing operations is expected to be between 28% and 32%. The increase is a result of the lower level of pretax income. Capital expenditures for 2016 are expected to be approximately $1.4 billion, including $1.15 billion for the Deepwater Conqueror, Deepwater Pontus and Deepwater Poseidon; and $180 million for capitalized interest. Maintenance CapEx is estimated to approximate $100 million. This reduced level of maintenance capital expenditures is consistent with our estimate for our limited number out-of-service days.
Turning now to our financial position. We have made the following assumptions and updated liquidity forecast through 2017. These include revenue efficiency of 95%, a limited number of new contract awards with day rates assumed at or near cash breakeven, existing drilling contracts remain intact and a working capital release of approximately $600 million in total for the years 2016, 2017.
Related to 2017, we expect total CapEx of approximately $600 million. This includes $175 million in newbuild shipyard payments, $150 million in capitalized interest and approximately $250 million in maintenance CapEx.
This maintenance CapEx guidance excludes the reactivation of the rigs for potential future contract awards. Based upon our current forecast, our projected liquidity at December 31, 2017, remains in the range $4 billion to $5 billion, with the vast majority of the contract termination payments received approximated forecasted operating cash flow under this contract. An exception is the recent cancellation of the DD1 contract. Unfortunately, we will not receive a termination payment as the customer has the contractual option to cancel with convenience. We estimate that this contract installation will reduce cash flow by approximately $56 million in 2016 and 2017. Terry will discuss this in more detail during his prepared comments. Our projection continues to include $3 billion undrawn revolving credit facility that remains available to us through mid-2019.
To conclude, we are very pleased with our operational results, including exceptional revenue efficiency and improvements in our cost structure. As we become a leaner organization, we are doing more with less. But the quality of our services remain high. We are not satisfied, however, and we'll continue to challenge the status quo to build on this momentum and strive for even greater performance to out-mitigate the reduced fleet utilization.
This concludes my prepared comments. I will now turn the call over to Terry. Terry?

headline: Transocean Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mark, and good day to everyone. To simply say the offshore drilling market continues to be challenging is an understatement. Yet in the fourth quarter, our teams, onshore and offshore, fired on all cylinders to deliver multiple contracts when oppo
componenttext:
Thanks, Mark, and good day to everyone. To simply say the offshore drilling market continues to be challenging is an understatement. Yet in the fourth quarter, our teams, onshore and offshore, fired on all cylinders to deliver multiple contracts when opportunities were scarce. With oil prices recently falling as low as the mid-20s and continuing to harbor around $30 a barrel, contract termination that began accelerating in December has continued. Fortunately, because of our strong contracts and relationships, we do not have other contracts in our backlog that permit uncompensated cancellation for convenience like the termination we recently announced related to the GlobalSantaFe Development Driller I.
I will reiterate what I said in our last earnings call, although demand is limited, we continue to fight for every opportunity in this highly competitive market. As a testament to our safety and operational performance and the creativity and tenacity of our marketing teams, we've added $378 million of contract backlog since the last earnings call, bringing our total 2015 to $763 million. We have contracted to reactivate the Henry Goodrich in Canada for 2 years, secured contracts to return the RIG 140 in India and the M.G. Hulme to work. We have also extended the contract for The Jack Bates in Australia and were awarded over 80 days for the Cajun Express in the Ivory Coast, while signing new contracts for active rigs, the Sedco 704 in U.K. and the Transocean Arctic in Norway. Our global footprint is vast and our ability to compete for work with our diverse fleet of rigs while capitalizing on our operational excellence is strong. As evidenced of our competitive positioning, I am especially pleased to report that since issuing our Fleet Status Report earlier this month, we were awarded a 6-month contract for the KG2 with an undisclosed operator and we expect to consummate several additional contracts in the near term. However, due to negotiations not yet being final and the competitiveness of the current market, we will refrain from commenting specifically on these today.
Our backlog as of February 11 was $15.5 billion dollars, the strongest in the industry, comprising primarily of IOCs with strong balance sheets. This balance sheet provides for solid cash flow generation with 78% of revenues contracted with the IOCs, 15% contracted with the independents and 7% contracted with that NOCs.
Turning to the current market. Challenging conditions are now likely to continue into 2017, negatively impacting both utilization and day rates while limiting rig contracting opportunities for all classes of rigs. Ultra-deepwater rates are near cash operating cost breakeven in most areas and market utilizations is down to 79%, with 27 rigs idle and 21 cold stacked.
To provided a little more perspective on the competitiveness of the market, the longest-term contracting opportunity currently in the Indian market has attracted 14 rigs from 10 different competitors. The associated rig classes range for fourth- to sixth-generation units with very competitive pricing expected.
Deepwater market utilization is down to 70% with only 3 fixtures year-to-date being recorded. This is coming off a total of 10 fixtures in '15, primarily in Australia and Asia. There are currently 10 idle and 11 cold-stacked deepwater rigs.
In India, the second ONGC 2-year tender attracted 8 rigs from 7 different contractors ranging from second- to fourth-generation rigs. The bidding on these opportunities will also be very competitive. Mid-water utilization is at 69% with 3 fixtures contracted year-to-date for U.K. and Norway. This adds to a total of 19 fixtures in 2015. Currently, there are 16 idle mid-water rigs and 15 units cold stacked. There are 47 cold-stacked units plus 48 floaters that are retired or being held for sale, with Transocean accounting for over 40% of the combined total. We expect these numbers to continue increasing with the overcapacity of supply and near-term lack of demand, forcing the retirement of more assets. The difficult macro conditions are also resulting in more customers terminating contracts early. This further exacerbates the oversupply floater market and as a direct result of customers curtailing parts of their offshore programs to preserve liquidity.
Despite the severity of the downturn, there are some emerging opportunities we are discussing with customers. Some are taking the countercyclical approach of contracting low-cost solutions for their programs later in '16 and into ''17, realizing the benefit of the reduced day rates to their overall project economics.
The jackup market continues to deteriorate as a result of increased market oversupply. This is also being exacerbated by a few rigs being cold stacked or scrapped, and the newbuild deliveries continue unabated. Utilization and day rates are rapidly declining. Marketed utilization is approximately 72% with 119 rigs currently warm stacked and 65 cold stacked. With the relatively low cost associated with stacking jackup rigs, scrapping activity is expected to be slower.
Unlike the floater market, NOCs are leveraging their local market dominance and renegotiating day rates lower based on the decline in oil prices. Industry delays of newbuild deliveries for both ultra-deepwater assets and jackups provides a medium-term relief in the excess rig supply. But continued industry attrition and stacking will contribute the most to permanently correcting the global oversupply situation.
Overall, our customers are focused on reducing costs but remain keenly focused on improving operational and safety performance. Additionally, with the duration of this downturn increasing, balance sheet strength of drilling contractors and their long-term viability are becoming key selection criteria for operators. With our strong liquidity, industry-leading backlog, diverse fleet and excellent safety and operational track record, we are positioning Transocean to increase our market-leading position. As such, we are keenly focused on extending both our customer and stakeholder expectations.
This concludes my overview of the market. So I will turn it over to Brad.

componenttext: This is either for either one of you, Jeremy or Mark. I know you've talked in the past about your ability to potentially tap into secured financing for $1 billion or more on the 4 newbuild with Shell. Any further color there on the visibility of that avenue in this market?

headline: Transocean Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Angie. Look, as we discussed in the past, we are very fortunate to have 4 of the best contracts against 4 of the best ultra-deepwater drillships in the industry. So those are highly marketable assets to raise additional secured financing. We are e
componenttext: Thanks, Angie. Look, as we discussed in the past, we are very fortunate to have 4 of the best contracts against 4 of the best ultra-deepwater drillships in the industry. So those are highly marketable assets to raise additional secured financing. We are evaluating options, apparently as you can imagine. But it's a tough market out there. Not only is the energy market difficult, but the banks also are having a pretty tough time. So until we actually get something completed, we're not going to comment further on this. But you can be sure that we are focused on using those assets in the most effective way to be able to raise additional financing, to be able to increase our backlog liquidity as we navigate this downturn.

headline: Transocean Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Okay, very, very helpful. And then one for Terry. I mean, congrats, Terry, on getting a handful of contracts in this market. Obviously, very challenging but impressive. So on the Exxon contract, you mentioned the other contracts have cancellations f
componenttext: Okay. Okay, very, very helpful. And then one for Terry. I mean, congrats, Terry, on getting a handful of contracts in this market. Obviously, very challenging but impressive. So on the Exxon contract, you mentioned the other contracts have cancellations for convenience without compensation. Could you talk a little bit about the Petrobras contracts and if there's anything unique on the contracts as far as termination for convenience or cause?

headline: Transocean Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Angie. And our contracting relationship with Petrobras is much like our competitors, it's all the same contract. So they don't deviate or negotiate anything different with any of us. So it's their standards. So they can terminate for cause, but it
componenttext: Thanks, Angie. And our contracting relationship with Petrobras is much like our competitors, it's all the same contract. So they don't deviate or negotiate anything different with any of us. So it's their standards. So they can terminate for cause, but it is for cause. And we haven't seen anything else from them to suggest that, that would be anything other than that. So we don't -- I'm sorry?

headline: Transocean Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was going to say our performance with Petrobras has been outstanding.
componenttext: I was going to say our performance with Petrobras has been outstanding.

headline: Transocean Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, absolutely. So we don't have anything there. So what we've said is we've gone through every contract. We do this all the time. Every contract is solid. I think a testament to that, I mean, look at the early termination we've gotten. Even though it's
componenttext: Yes, absolutely. So we don't have anything there. So what we've said is we've gone through every contract. We do this all the time. Every contract is solid. I think a testament to that, I mean, look at the early termination we've gotten. Even though it's a sad thing, the early terminated rig, because our crews go home and the rig doesn't operate, we've collected over $500 million in the last couple of months on these unfortunate early terminations. So that should demonstrate strengths of the contracting opportunities that we have left in our fleet.

headline: Transocean Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then one final one for Jeremy. I know you mentioned some thoughts in the past on industry consolidation and that your board was actually supportive of consolidation. Any further thought as we go along here in the cycle?
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then one final one for Jeremy. I know you mentioned some thoughts in the past on industry consolidation and that your board was actually supportive of consolidation. Any further thought as we go along here in the cycle?

headline: Transocean Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I would say that we remain committed to high-grading our fleet, certainly. And we would certainly like to lead the consolidation of the market. However, we have 3 very important criteria that have to be met in that process: one is asset quality, two
componenttext: Sure. I would say that we remain committed to high-grading our fleet, certainly. And we would certainly like to lead the consolidation of the market. However, we have 3 very important criteria that have to be met in that process: one is asset quality, two would be near-term liquidity and three would be a reasonable and realistic valuation. And so aligning those 3 is a bit challenging but we're continuing to pursue opportunities and still believe that ultimately we will lead this consolidation efforts.

headline: Transocean Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Next we'll hear from James West with Evercore ISI.
