componenttext: Good day, and welcome to the First Quarter 2016 Earnings Call for Transocean Ltd. Today's conference is being recorded. At this time, I'd like to turn the conference over to Bradley Alexander, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Transocean Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Lauren. Good day, and welcome to Transocean's First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. A copy of the press release covering our financial results, along with supporting statements and schedules, including reconciliations and disclosures reg
componenttext:
Thank you, Lauren. Good day, and welcome to Transocean's First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. A copy of the press release covering our financial results, along with supporting statements and schedules, including reconciliations and disclosures regarding non-GAAP financial measures, are posted on the company's website at deepwater.com. 
Joining me on this morning's call are Jeremy Thigpen, President and Chief Executive Officer; Mark Mey, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and Terry Bonno, Senior Vice President, Marketing. 
During the course of this call, participants may make certain forward-looking statements regarding various matters related to our business and company that are not historical facts. Such statements are based upon the current expectations and certain assumptions of management and are, therefore, subject to certain risks and uncertainties. Many factors could cause actual results to differ materially. Please refer to our SEC filings for more information regarding our forward-looking statements, including the risks and uncertainties that could impact our future results. Also, please note that the company undertakes no duty to update or revise forward-looking statements. [Operator Instructions] 
Thank you very much. And now, I'll now turn the call over to Jeremy.

headline: Transocean Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to our employees, customers and investors participating in today's call. Joining me today or Mark Mey, Chief Financial Officer, who will later provide the financial overview; and Terry Bonno, Senior Vice President of Marketing, w
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to our employees, customers and investors participating in today's call. Joining me today or Mark Mey, Chief Financial Officer, who will later provide the financial overview; and Terry Bonno, Senior Vice President of Marketing, who will then provide an overview of the market. 
As reported in yesterday's earnings release, the company generated adjusted net income of $254 million in the first quarter or $0.69 per diluted share on $1.3 billion of revenue. Although a few puts and takes in the quarter, which Mark will explain, we are very pleased that our underlying operating performance continue to deliver strong revenue efficiency of 95% as well as further cost reduction. Of note, we deliver this high level of performance while breaking in the Deepwater Thalassa, the first of 4 newbuild drillships commencing 10-year contracts with Shell. 
As such, I would like to personally take a moment to thank our newbuild project teams, our crews offshore and our shore-based support for your exemplary work in the first quarter. 
As we move to the balance of 2016, we will continue our intense focus on safety and operational integrity, both of which continue to improve. On uptime performance, which continues to average 95% or better across our fleet; on cost control, which resulted in meaningful sequential reductions in operating and maintenance expense and G&A expense; on the high grading of our fleet, which we demonstrated in the first quarter with the addition of 1 new high-specification ultra-deepwater drillship and the retirement of an older rig; and on the further strengthening of our customer relationship, which helped us to secure additional contracts in a highly competitive implement. 
Speaking first about cost control, we continue to identify and realize opportunities to reduce operating, stacking and overhead costs to maximize our operating margins in the face of declining activity. For rigs under contract, we are streamlining maintenance activities, which are delivering sustainable cost savings while simultaneously increasing uptime. 
In addition to recognizing savings associated with process deficiencies, we continue to work closely with our supply partners to drive cost out of manufacturing, maintenance, service and repair. To date, the realized savings are ranging between 20% and 30% for some of our costliest areas, including riser inspection and certification, engine overhauls and crane maintenance. 
The rigs that need to be stacked, we challenged our teams to look beyond conventional practices especially when it came to our dynamically positioned rigs. To find ways to preserve these assets in the most cost-effective manner. As a direct result of their expertise and ingenuity, we are now clustering these rigs in benign sheltered environments offshore using a temporary mooring system. As part of the process, we are protecting critical equipment and controls use and preservation fluids and dehumidification units to ensure that the rigs are in condition to be reactivated in an expedient and cost-effective manner when market conditions improve. 
As a result of these actions, stacking costs associated with these rigs have decreased by approximately 75% since last year to less than $20,000 a day. For our shore base support and overhead cost, we have almost finalized the restructuring of our organization which includes centralizing our global support functions in Houston. This eliminated or significantly downsized our hub offices around the world while reducing barriers between our management and the rig. While streamlining maintenance processes, stacking rig and restructuring the organization are not necessarily easy and require tough decisions, we are pleased with our progress in these 3 key areas of cost reduction, which will continue to positively impact our operating results going forward. 
Turning to our fleet, we are pleased to welcome the Deepwater Proteus to Transocean. the Deepwater Proteus, which is the second of 4 newbuild drillships contracted to work for Shell, is expected to commence operations in the coming days. In addition to the Deepwater Proteus, in March, we christened the Deepwater Conqueror at the Daiwu shipyard in Korea. This ultra-deepwater drillship is scheduled to commence her 5-year contract with Chevron and the Gulf of Mexico at the end of the year. 
As a reminder, all of these rigs are designed to operate in water depths of up to 12,000 feet and drill wells to a depth of 40,000 feet. They were constructed with Transocean's patented dual activity drilling technology, industry-leading hoisting capacity and dual BOP's. 
These rigs are fully outfitted to be upgraded with 20,000 PSI BOP's, in short, they are excellent additions to our fleet. While discussing the newbuilds, and as previously announced, we have reached agreements to delay the deliveries of our uncontracted floaters and jackups into 2020. 
These deferrals will help us preserve near-term, while continuing with our fleet renewal strategy albeit at a slower pace. In addition to our own new builds bills, we are now seeing more sixth-generation deepwater rigs marketed for sale. As stated in previous calls, we will continue to evaluate these opportunities with our interest limited to those assets that would enhance our overall fleet quality, while furthering our fleet strategy. However, it's important to note that we continue to place a very high priority on liquidity and we'll remain selective in regard to any potential transactions. 
As part of high grading the feet, we also continue to assess capability and marketability of our existing rigs. Through this review, we made a decision in the first quarter to recycle the midwater floater, that Transocean John Shaw, increasing our total rigs recycled or held for sale since the start of the downturn to 25. 
As we move through the year, we will continue this process and we'll remain decisive in determining the future of each rig as the market continues to evolve. 
Before turning the call over to Mark and then Terry, I'd like to take a moment to talk at a high level about the market. As you well know, the near-term market outlook remains very challenging. At this point, we do not expect to see a meaningful recovery in rig activity before 2017 as customer budgets have been set for 2016 and are unlikely to improve until there's further recovery in the price of oil and confidence regarding its sustainability is bolstered. Even so, remain very confident in the long-term fundamentals of offshore exploration and development and the drilling industry's inevitable recovery. 
I visit with customers on a regular basis and my recent conversations with them have reinforce our position that future hydrocarbon supply require significant production from offshore and more specifically from deepwater fields. Our largest customers have significant deepwater reserves and they recognized without increased activity, they will face production declines and reserve replacement challenges that will be difficult and costly to reverse and overcome. 
North America, Venezuela, Mexico and the U.K. have all experienced year-over-year production declines and we expect this will only increase as the recent deficiencies and reinvestment continue to impact overall supply. Additionally, in my customer discussions, it's becoming more evident that they recognize the benefits of narrowing their supplier base fourth quarter services to a few select partners that can help them to deliver their operational and financial objectives. This market downturn has allowed them to cherry pick the highest quality contractors and service providers and move toward agreement that should promote direct negotiations on some of their prioritized opportunities. 
Through both pricing concessions and a more collaborative approach between operators, contractors and service providers, the high cost previously associated with much of the Deepwater activity are beginning to abate. The industry is now witnessing sustainable cost reductions that will ultimately drive economic development of large offshore projects well below previous price per barrel requirements. 
As wells are drilled faster and more precisely and production equipment and facilities are engineered using more efficient approaches, the competitiveness of these assets will continue to improve. As oil prices has then recover and the liquidity profile for our customers improves, we expect the offshore drilling activity declines we have experienced will reverse. When that time comes, we are confident that our stacked rigs are not only being preserved in the most cost-effective manner but in ways that will enable their swift reactivation and return to operation. Until that time, we will continue to prudently manage our balance sheet and cost structure while remaining intently focused on operations to ensure we remain the offshore industry's driller of choice. 
I'll now turn the call over to Mark.

headline: Transocean Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jeremy, and good day to all. During today's call, I will recap the first quarter results, provide an update to our 2016 guidance and discuss our balance sheet and liquidity position. For the first quarter of 2016, we reported net income attri
componenttext:
Thank you, Jeremy, and good day to all. During today's call, I will recap the first quarter results, provide an update to our 2016 guidance and discuss our balance sheet and liquidity position. 
For the first quarter of 2016, we reported net income attributable to controlling interest of $249 million or $0.68 per diluted share. These results included $5 million or $0.01 per diluted share in net unfavorable items that are detailed in our press release. Excluding these items, adjusted net income was $254 million or $0.69 per diluted share. 
Contract drilling revenue for the first quarter of 2016 decreased by $345 million, sequentially to $1.1 billion. The decrease was primarily due to reduced activity associated with 634 fewer operating days during the quarter. Our operational and technical teams continued to perform at a very high level, delivering another quarter of 95% revenue efficiency. Other revenue decreased $165 million sequentially to $230 million during the quarter. This included $209 million in early contract termination fees associated with the Discoverer Deep Seas and the Deepwater Millennium. 
When adjusting these early contract termination fees or contract drilling revenues, expected during first quarter, these rigs were as planned, $133 million relate today's beyond March 31, 2016. 
First quarter operating and maintenance expense was $655 million, down from $794 million in the prior quarter. The 16% decrease was largely due to lower activity, cost savings related to operational and restructuring initiatives and reduced cost for our fifth- and sixth-gen DP floaters. This was partially offset by the $45 million of reactivation costs for Henry Goodrich expense during the quarter. The Goodrich begin strategic contract with later this month. 
Additionally, we recognize $18 million of mobilization costs on the geo- shift development driller #1 that was previously anticipated to be recorded in the second quarter. Also, first quarter O&M expenses were negatively impacted by $3 million of restructuring costs associated with employee severances. 
G&A expenses totaled $43 million, down $15 million from the prior quarter, which reflects our ongoing restructuring efforts. Our operating margin including G&A expense was approximately 47% for the quarter, driven higher by the impact of early contract terminations included in other revenue above. 
The first quarter annual effective tax rate was 22.8%, compared with 13.1% in the prior quarter. This increase was due to the lower adjusted pretax income and change in the mix of operating results from certain jurisdictions. We ended the quarter with $2.6 billion in cash and cash equivalents, reflecting cash flow from operations for the first quarter of $631 million. This includes our working capital release of $128 million. 
Capital expenditures for the first quarter totaled $368 million, largely associated with payments on the newbuilds. Since the last call, we opportunistically repurchased $100 million of debt at a cost of $84 million. As [indiscernible] budgets were settled after the end of the quarter, the first quarter's balance sheet does not reflect these net repurchases. 
Cash interest savings for these debt repurchases is approximately $23 million over the remaining term. This brings our total repurchases for the 3 quarters to $603 million at a cost of $557 million and aggregate interest cost savings of approximately $105 million through maturity of this debt. 
I will now provide an update on our financial expectations for 2016 and our liquidity expectations through 2017. Our 2016 revenue efficiency guidance remains at 95%. Other revenue for 2016 is expected to be between $260 million and $270 million. This includes customer reimbursables and the early contract termination fees recognized to date in 2016. 
We expect full year operating and maintenance expense to raise between $2.1 billion and $2.3 billion. The 6% decrease from our previous guidance reflects reduced fleet activity, primarily as a result of early contract terminations. Consistent with activity, O&M cost will be higher in the first half of 2016 and trend lower toward the latter quarters as number of rigs active decline during the year. 
We estimate that O&M expense for the second quarter will be in the range of between $550 million and $570 million. We also expect the second half of the year to benefit from reduced expenses and the beneficial cost impact resulting from a smaller streamlined support organization. 
Full year G&A expenses are expected to be approximately $160 million. So [indiscernible] O&M, this is anticipated to decrease as we progress through the year. We estimate that the second quarter G&A will be approximately $45 million. Full year 2016 net interest expense is expected to be between $360 million and $370 million. 
Net interest expense includes capitalized interest and interest income of $185 million and $10 million, respectively. Full year 2016 annual effective tax rate is expected to be in the range between 28% and 30% as we expect higher tax rate for the remainder of the year. This is due to a significant reduction in net income from operations as fewer rigs are working and some have lower day rates. 
There are no changes to our expected 2016 depreciation expense. Capital expenditures for the remainder of 2016 are expected to be approximately $1.1 billion, including approximately $1 billion for the newbuild Deepwater Conqueror, Deepwater Pontus and Deepwater Poseidon. This amount includes capitalized interest. We expect maintenance CapEx to be approximately $80 million for the remainder of 2016. 
Turning now to our financial position. Since our last call, we have enhanced our liquidity position by announcing 2 separate future newbuild delivery deferrals. In early march, we agreed with to defer delivery and related payments of our 5 high-specification jackups. This defers approximately $735 million from 2018 and 2019 into 2020. 
In April, we amended the construction contracts with Jurong as a late delivery of 2 newbuild ultra-deepwater drillships by approximately 6 months each. These 2 proprietary Jurong has began [indiscernible] 3 [indiscernible] design drillships and are now expected to be delivered in the first and third quarter of 2020. This defers approximately $420 million from 2019 into 2020. 
We continue to evaluate the secured financing options in our 5 contracted newbuild drillships. As you are aware, these rigs are highly marketable assets due to the quality of their assets and the respective contracts as well as the contract duration. We'll provide a more update in due course. 
We reiterate our assumptions related to our updated liquidity forecast through 2017. This include revenue efficiency of 95%; a limited number of new contract awards with day rates assumed to be at or near cash breakeven; working capital release of approximately $500 million in total for the years 2016 and 2017. This includes the previously mentioned $128 million of release in the first quarter. 
In 2017, we expect total CapEx of approximately $625 million. This includes $375 million in newbuild CapEx and $250 million for maintenance CapEx. Based on our current forecast, our projected liquidity at December 31, 2017, remains in the range of $4 billion to $5 billion. 
Our projection includes our $3 billion undrawn revolving credit facility that remains available to us through [indiscernible] 2019. 
To conclude, we are very pleased with our strong operational results, adequate liquidity and substantial contract backlog. We also believe the quality of our fleet, together with our propriety [indiscernible] focused on efficient rig reactivation, better positions us to win more than our fair share of future drilling contracts, increasing our contract backlog and further reupholstering our financial strength. 
This concludes my prepared comments. I'll now turn the call over to Terry.

headline: Transocean Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mark, and good day, to everyone. As you all know, the market remains very challenging despite the recent increase in oil prices from the multiyear lows experienced early in the year, operators remain hesitant to commit to long-term project that re
componenttext:
Thanks, Mark, and good day, to everyone. As you all know, the market remains very challenging despite the recent increase in oil prices from the multiyear lows experienced early in the year, operators remain hesitant to commit to long-term project that requires significant levels of capital, however, as Jeremy mentioned, we continue to have manyfold dialogue with our customers and they remain firmly committed to their deepwater assets as they view this as a necessary source of future reserves. 
The real question is around the velocity with which these customers will ultimately add rigs in response to declines in reserve displacements and production. Even more so than in past cycles, our customers realize that the reduction in offshore drilling is not sustainable, especially considering the fact that the global demand for energy continues to increase. 
In the meantime, as we await the eventual recovery, we will continue to position our fleet to take advantage of opportunities in the market. As stated in previous conference calls, our teams continue to battle for every opportunity in this highly competitive market. 
Looking at ways that we can best align with our customers oil plans and business objectives. This approach has once again, proven to be successful as we signed several new contracts resulting in the addition of $138 million of contract backlog since last earnings call, bringing our 2016 total to $184 million. 
In our ultra-deepwater fleet, we extended the duration on the Deepwater Invictus by adding a 2-well contract at $350,000 a day in Trinidad, with additional bonus opportunity. This contract award highlights our stellar operational performance for BHP and our willingness to work with the customer to best meet their project priorities. We've also secured a 6-month contract on the KG2 returning her to work after being idled. You are like aware of the recent announcement from Hurricane Energy with respect to the Pittsburgh, we've waited to formally announce this contract pending approval of their board early this month. 
In India, we were awarded a 3-year contract of the midwater floater in, also returning her to work after being idle. In total, our fleet and commercial strategy enabled us to return 3 idled rigs to our active fleet and to further extend work for another rig during the quarter. 
As a result, our backlog as of April 21, is an industry leading $14.6 billion. This foundation provides solid future cash flow generation with 79% of the revenues contracted with the super majors, 13% contracted with the independents and 8% contracted with the national oil companies. And further, we do not have contract in our current backlog that permit cancellation for convenience without compensation. 
Turning to the global market. While we are seeing some positive movement in the macro environment and improve confidence regarding oil prices for the second half of '16, we expect challenging conditions are likely to continue into '17 impacting both utilization and day rates. In order for contacting conditions to improve for next year's budgeting cycle, customers need to see these improved oil prices sustain in the coming months. 
As the supermarket stands today, ultra-deepwater market utilization is down 79% with 32 rigs idled and 23 cold-stacked. Year-to-date, we have seen 11 fixtures that have been executed, mostly in Asia and India, in addition to a few South America and Africa with the majority being short-term work. Longer-term fixtures were largely agreed in '15 but executed in '16. 
With the amount of rig availability in the market, including farmout opportunities, we'll continue to see strong competition for every opportunity. Another example of this is increasing competition as we understand it as the recently announced Chevron Nigeria tender for 2 years, which drew numerous contractors. 
As we wait at the award of the long-term expiration tender in India expected to be within the next 2 weeks, we understand the development work requiring 2 additional 1,500 meter DPs for almost 3 years term per rig commencing in 2017. 
It's encouraging to see some customers are taking advantage of the lower pricing environment to pursue with their project. Deepwater market utilization is down 71%, driven 5 fixtures year-to-date, primarily in Asia and Europe. They're currently 11 idled and 10 cold-stacked deepwater units while we await the result of the ongoing 6-meter tender in India. We're also happy to see another long-term tender about to come to the market. ONGC is expected to release the department tender for 1 more unit for almost 2-year term that will commence in '17. 
Mid-water utilization is at 69% with 6 fixtures contracted year-to-date mainly in India and Norway, currently there are 16 midwater rigs that are idled and 18 units cold-stacked. As previously stated, continued stability and improvement in commodity pricing will increase the number of opportunities for these assets in the U.K. and Norway. 
Industry-wide, there are 151 cold-stacked floaters [indiscernible] 53 [ph] units are retired or being held for sale. We expect these numbers to increase with a relative high level of supply and near-term lack of demand forcing the retirement of most asset. 
The jackup market continues to deteriorate as a result of increased market oversupply. This is being exacerbated by very few rigs being scrapped to their minimal cost associated with cold stacking and the growing supply of newbuild rigs being delivered. Marketing utilization is approximately 71% with 120 rigs currently idle and 69 cold-stacked. 
There have been 21 fixtures year-to-date mainly in the Middle East, Asia and U.K. Unlike the floater market, national oil companies are leveraging their local market dominance and contract terms and either renegotiating day rates or outright canceling the remaining term. Overall, our customers remain focused on cost reduction, operational excellence and safe operation. And they remain committed to delivering their core business, which will undoubtedly include Deepwater exploration and development. Until we experience the uptick in demand for our assets and services, we will move forward with our strong liquidity, industry-leading backlog and excellent operational and safety performance as we continue to position Transocean to increase our market-leading position as we progress through the downturn. 
This concludes my overview of the market, so I will turn it over to Brad.

componenttextpreview: Jeremy or I guess, Terry can answer this question. So as we progress through 2015, we've started to see a pickup in contract terminations, not only for Transocean but across the industry. And then it seems like it accelerated again in early part of '16. A
componenttext: Jeremy or I guess, Terry can answer this question. So as we progress through 2015, we've started to see a pickup in contract terminations, not only for Transocean but across the industry. And then it seems like it accelerated again in early part of '16. Are we at a point now we are generally customers that were going to cancel contracts are sort of have that behind them? Or is this something that we think is going to continue to sort of plague the industry over the next 6 to 12 months?

headline: Transocean Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Greg, good morning. I think that what we have to look at is from our own conversations with our customers, it's really hard for us -- difficult for us to project what will happen to our competitors. But for those folks that are suffering for the low
componenttext: Well, Greg, good morning. I think that what we have to look at is from our own conversations with our customers, it's really hard for us -- difficult for us to project what will happen to our competitors. But for those folks that are suffering for the lower commodity prices, I think we will see some more contract terminations or probably a little bit lower contract renegotiation. But from our fleet, in our perspective, we are not hearing those conversations as of today. In fact, we are in conversations with some extensions of our fleet. So we believe that with our strong backlog that our conversations, perhaps are going to be a little bit different than our competitor.

headline: Transocean Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that's the point, almost 80% of our backlog is with the super majors and 90% is with investment-grade companies. So we feel really good about the strength of backlog and being able to convert that into future earnings and cash flow. Never say neve
componenttext: I think that's the point, almost 80% of our backlog is with the super majors and 90% is with investment-grade companies. So we feel really good about the strength of backlog and being able to convert that into future earnings and cash flow. Never say never though. It depends on what happens in the market, obviously, but right now, the conversations -- we're not having those conversations with customers.

headline: Transocean Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016

componenttext: And then Mark, just for you, I saw that you hit in April, you brought back some debt. I'm just trying to sort of gauge why April, why not earlier this year? And then any color on which of the bonds were actually repurchased?

componenttext: Yes, sure, Greg. We focused mainly, as I've mentioned to you guys in the past, focus mainly on the new debt maturities, so we buy -- we've been buying back to 16, 17, 18s, mainly with some focus on the 20s to 22s. It just so worked out the previous quarter that our opportunity to actually attract bonds, I guess, the bond availability was late in March.

headline: Transocean Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, Ian, I think, we've been very clear in the past that we have substantial liquidity. We have a industry-leading backlog and I think we have a debt maturity profile that allows us to avoid the equity market. I think we'll be opportunistic with
componenttext: Good morning, Ian, I think, we've been very clear in the past that we have substantial liquidity. We have a industry-leading backlog and I think we have a debt maturity profile that allows us to avoid the equity market. I think we'll be opportunistic with regard to adding and refinancing our maturities with secured debt options in the event so that we're able to achieve that. But at this stage, we do not feel that equity is the right solution for Transocean.

headline: Transocean Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Very clear, thanks, Marc. I have a follow-up also for you, if you don't mind. I'm looking at your 5th-gen rigs are stacked, it looks like 14 fifth-generation rigs are mainly stacked or a couple of them are idled or maybe almost stacked. Can you comment on
componenttext: Very clear, thanks, Marc. I have a follow-up also for you, if you don't mind. I'm looking at your 5th-gen rigs are stacked, it looks like 14 fifth-generation rigs are mainly stacked or a couple of them are idled or maybe almost stacked. Can you comment on the carrying value of those? And what your -- what the impairment test for those rigs looks like for those rigs going forward? And weather we should think about of was built to their going forward?

headline: Transocean Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, as you well know, the impairment test is based on the remaining life of the assets in these assets, predominantly, delivered around 2,000. So you're looking at asset that would last through 2020. So given the fact that we have a significant tail on
componenttext: Well, as you well know, the impairment test is based on the remaining life of the assets in these assets, predominantly, delivered around 2,000. So you're looking at asset that would last through 2020. So given the fact that we have a significant tail on average about 15 years or so the remaining life of these assets, I think it is fair to say that we feel very strongly that given the way that we have approach our stacking of these assets, they've been cold-stacked with the intention of reactivating these rigs very quickly and cost-effectively. So as the market does recover in '18, '19, as Jeremy has mention in the past, we believe these [indiscernible] will come back to the market and we'd be able to earn sufficient cash flows to offset the carrying value over that remaining period.

headline: Transocean Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Angie, we typically look at our liquidity as fungible so cash and revolver. So we fully expect to be able to use a combination of both to retire the 2016's. The potential secured debt is opportunistic on our part. We don’t' feel that its necessary to ra
componenttext: Angie, we typically look at our liquidity as fungible so cash and revolver. So we fully expect to be able to use a combination of both to retire the 2016's. The potential secured debt is opportunistic on our part. We don’t' feel that its necessary to raise that debt, to retire the '16's or the '17's in that matter. So anything that get in addition to our current equity in a form of secured debt would be over and above what we have planned mainly through this cycle.

componenttext: Good morning, Ole, this is Mark, look, we've been very clear in the past on these costs, that currently the value of the that we enjoy when we listed Transocean Partners for the first time has reversed. So it's not economic for us to be able to use Transocean Partners in the capacity which was envisioned initially. That is still our intention if and when the market does recover for both the offshore drilling industry and for yield-based vehicles. So the intention there would be to nurture Transocean partner as best as we can and recognize the winning opportunity we provide ourselves that will utilize the vehicle and the capacity which we intended.

componenttext: Yes, it's a good question. So we believe that the interest, starting with the majors, is very high in Brazil. componenttext: I think I am very pleased with my prepared comments with regard to what the onetime cost we saw in the first quarter with regard to the reactivation costs on the Goodrich. The mobilization which we recognize in the quarter, some severance costs. But others that trend will be Q1 will be higher, Q4 will be the lowest for the year because as we modeled out our operating activity with the number of rigs, those declines throughout the year. That being said, we have to factor in the additional Thalassa, the point use and obviously, that reactivation of Goodrich which will go to nearly every direction. But in general, you're going to see a significant reduction in operating costs. In addition, as you know, with the first quarter's contract cancellations, we announce that those rigs are going to be cold-stacked. There are certainly cost associated with cold-stacked units which is expense in the first 30 to 60 days. So you'll see that flow through in the February, March and some of them, April time frame as well.

componenttext: I think that there's going to be few opportunities, more opportunities for land and extend. But it's something a little bit different than our competitors have done. We did, actually with BHP in Trinidad, we actually inserted a contract and then moved all of our terms to the right in Trinidad to help better align that program with BHP's objectives. So you might see a bit more of that where we were able to do that and certainly remains focus on our cash flow. But as far as land and expand, we are in discussions with a few customers and again, I think we will see a few more.

componenttext: I wanted to -- this is maybe more for Terry. In your prepared comments, you talked about kind of the commodity would have just a higher with kind of the model you're going to the budgeting cycle, maybe to change these the kind of a trajectory where the demanded. Is there a chance that you may not get enough momentum in kind of [indiscernible] of your budgeting cycle to have things offset meaningfully in '17 or maybe the budgeting cycle being much more fluid going on? And just how customers and how your kind of view on that is given the fact that the commodity market seems to be a little bit more accommodating.

headline: Transocean Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Darren, I think that was 3 or 4 questions in one. I'll try to go through all of them again. I think we've been pretty clear, to your first question do when do you -- do we see the uptake in our price and the sustainability of it early enough for customers
componenttext: Darren, I think that was 3 or 4 questions in one. I'll try to go through all of them again. I think we've been pretty clear, to your first question do when do you -- do we see the uptake in our price and the sustainability of it early enough for customers to build it into their budgets for next year. We're not sure. And we said publicly, we don't know the answer. We said publicly, we expect '16 and '17 to be challenging. So I think it would be a pleasant surprise if oil prices continue to be up to the right and customers that confident ahead of their budgeting cycle where we could see meaningful improvement and activity next year, but we're not building on that business right now. So that was 1 piece of it. I think the second piece of it in terms of how quickly can we respond, it's going to depend on the rig, right, and the condition of the rig. We have a team that is both responsible for the destacking the rig and also that same team is responsible for reactivating the rigs. So we're doing everything that we possibly can to ensure we are per serving this equipment, we're preserving these rigs in the way that we can reactivate them cost effectively and quickly but it's going to depend on the rig. Some of them may take 60 days, some of them may take 120 days but that's kind of the range of reactivation that we're looking at across the fleet right now.

componenttextpreview: Darren, this is Mark. I think it's safe to assume that you're going to have dollars spent across the board, right. You're looking at dollars being spent offshore, shallow offshore, harsh environment, Deepwater Gulf of Mexico and elsewhere. So I think what
componenttext: Darren, this is Mark. I think it's safe to assume that you're going to have dollars spent across the board, right. You're looking at dollars being spent offshore, shallow offshore, harsh environment, Deepwater Gulf of Mexico and elsewhere. So I think what's going to be an interesting driver of the recovery is the makeup and financial viability and strength of our customer base. So as we look around the world and we look at the basins and the main customers in those areas, that's going to drive how they return back to the market. I think Jeremy made a comment in his prepared statements around Venezuela, for example. If you don't have any funds available, you're not going to be able to attract service companies or E&P companies to be able to start -- restart your production. So I think we have to think about that as well in the context of what's going to be first, second and what's going to be most viable on a perspective basis.

componenttext: And actually I want to follow up from some of for commentary there, Mark, I'm thinking about recovery. If we look back at prior offshore cycles, typically jackups and midwater tender react first because those customers will tend to spend cash flow first. In your mind, is there a case to be made that ultra-deepwater activity could recover as fast as some of those markets, maybe faster than they had his point because some of the major cutbacks so severely, just be curious what you're hearing from customers if you think that's a possibility.

headline: Transocean Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: As you look historically, you're right, because it's easy to plug and play on the jackups and the mid-water fleet and we certainly expect the U.K. and Norway to react pretty quickly. In the ultra-deepwater space, we do have the independent who are telling
componenttext: As you look historically, you're right, because it's easy to plug and play on the jackups and the mid-water fleet and we certainly expect the U.K. and Norway to react pretty quickly. In the ultra-deepwater space, we do have the independent who are telling us that at $50 looks really great and they could do some plug-and-play. So I think we'll see that happen as long as we have some sustained momentum starting with the commodity price. But as far as the majors, I mean, they got to get a lot more stability, it takes a lot to do their feasibility study. So think we're going to see a pause so I think they are able to push their programs forward.

componenttextpreview: It's going to be a range. It's going to depend on the asset itself, but we've have a range on -- if you go through the different classes of rigs, I mean, the ultra-deepwater might be something between $20 million and $100 million, and I know that's a big
componenttext: It's going to be a range. It's going to depend on the asset itself, but we've have a range on -- if you go through the different classes of rigs, I mean, the ultra-deepwater might be something between $20 million and $100 million, and I know that's a big range but that's kind of where we are. As you go into some of the lower classes, that high-end comes down obviously may be into 70 and 60 range. Until we do it, we're not going to know, we got pretty good plans in place, we got pretty good idea what it is going to cost us, but until we actually execute, we're not going to know.

Good day, and welcome to the First Quarter 2016 Earnings Call for Transocean Ltd. Today's conference is being recorded.
At this time, I'd like to turn the conference over to Bradley Alexander, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Transocean Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Lauren. Good day, and welcome to Transocean's First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. A copy of the press release covering our financial results, along with supporting statements and schedules, including reconciliations and disclosures reg
componenttext:
Thank you, Lauren. Good day, and welcome to Transocean's First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. A copy of the press release covering our financial results, along with supporting statements and schedules, including reconciliations and disclosures regarding non-GAAP financial measures, are posted on the company's website at deepwater.com.
Joining me on this morning's call are Jeremy Thigpen, President and Chief Executive Officer; Mark Mey, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and Terry Bonno, Senior Vice President, Marketing.
During the course of this call, participants may make certain forward-looking statements regarding various matters related to our business and company that are not historical facts. Such statements are based upon the current expectations and certain assumptions of management and are, therefore, subject to certain risks and uncertainties. Many factors could cause actual results to differ materially. Please refer to our SEC filings for more information regarding our forward-looking statements, including the risks and uncertainties that could impact our future results. Also, please note that the company undertakes no duty to update or revise forward-looking statements. [Operator Instructions]
Thank you very much. And now, I'll now turn the call over to Jeremy.

headline: Transocean Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to our employees, customers, investors and analysts participating in today's call. Joining me today are Mark Mey, Chief Financial Officer, who will later provide the financial overview; and Terry Bonno, Senior Vice President of M
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to our employees, customers, investors and analysts participating in today's call. Joining me today are Mark Mey, Chief Financial Officer, who will later provide the financial overview; and Terry Bonno, Senior Vice President of Marketing, who will then provide an overview of the market.
As reported in yesterday's earnings release, the company generated adjusted net income of $254 million in the first quarter or $0.69 per diluted share on $1.3 billion of revenues. While there are a few puts and takes in the quarter, which Mark will explain, we are very pleased that our underlying operating performance continued to deliver strong revenue efficiency of 95% as well as further cost reductions. Of note, we delivered this high level of performance while breaking in the Deepwater Thalassa, the first of 4 newbuild drillships commencing 10-year contracts with Shell. As such, I would like to personally take a moment to thank our newbuild project teams, our crews offshore and our shore-based support for your exemplary work in the first quarter.
As we move to the balance of 2016, we will continue our intense focus on safety and operational integrity, both of which continued to improve; on uptime performance, which continues to average 95% or better across our fleet; on cost control, which resulted in meaningful sequential reductions in operating and maintenance expense and G&A expense; on the high grading of our fleet, which we demonstrated in the first quarter with the addition of 1 new high-specification ultra-deepwater drillship and the retirement of an older rig; and on the further strengthening of our customer relationships, which helped us to secure additional contracts in a highly competitive environment.
Speaking first about cost control, we continue to identify and realize opportunities to reduce operating, stacking and overhead costs to maximize our operating margins in the face of declining activity. For rigs under contract, we are streamlining maintenance activities, which are delivering sustainable cost savings while simultaneously increasing uptime.
In addition to recognizing savings associated with process deficiencies, we continue to work closely with our supply partners to drive cost out of manufacturing, maintenance, service and repair. To date, the realized savings are ranging between 20% and 30% for some of our costliest areas, including riser inspection and certification, engine overhauls and crane maintenance.
For rigs that need to be stacked, we challenged our teams to look beyond conventional practices, especially when it came to our dynamically positioned rigs, to find ways to preserve these assets in the most cost-effective manner. As a direct result of their expertise and ingenuity, we are now clustering these rigs in benign sheltered environments offshore using a temporary mooring system. As part of the process, we are protecting critical equipment and controls using preservation fluids and dehumidification units to ensure that the rigs are in condition to be reactivated in an expedient and cost-effective manner when market conditions improve.
As a result of these actions, stacking costs associated with these rigs have decreased by approximately 75% since last year to less than $20,000 a day. For our shore-based support and overhead cost, we have almost finalized the restructuring of our organization, which includes centralizing our global support functions in Houston. This eliminated or significantly downsized our hub offices around the world while reducing layers between our management and the rig. While streamlining maintenance processes, stacking rigs and restructuring the organization are not necessarily easy and require tough decisions, we are pleased with our progress in these 3 key areas of cost reduction, which will continue to positively impact our operating results going forward.
Turning to our fleet, we are pleased to welcome the Deepwater Proteus to Transocean. the Deepwater Proteus, which is the second of 4 newbuild drillships contracted to work for Shell, is expected to commence operations in the coming days. In addition to the Deepwater Proteus, in March, we christened the Deepwater Conqueror at the Daewoo shipyard in Korea. This ultra-deepwater drillship is scheduled to commence her 5-year contract with Chevron in the Gulf of Mexico at the end of the year.
As a reminder, all of these rigs are designed to operate in water depths of up to 12,000 feet and drill wells to a depth of 40,000 feet. They were constructed with Transocean's patented dual-activity drilling technology, industry-leading hoisting capacity and dual BOPs. These rigs are fully outfitted to be upgraded with 20,000 PSI BOP's. In short, they are excellent additions to our fleet.
While discussing the newbuilds, and as previously announced, we have reached agreements to delay the deliveries of our uncontracted floaters and jackups into 2020. These deferrals will help us preserve near-term while continuing with our fleet renewal strategy albeit at a slower pace. In addition to our own newbuilds, we are now seeing more sixth-generation deepwater rigs marketed for sale. As stated in previous calls, we will continue to evaluate these opportunities with our interest limited to those assets that would enhance our overall fleet quality while furthering our fleet strategy. However, it's important to note that we continue to place a very high priority on liquidity and will remain very selective in regard to any potential transactions.
As part of high grading the feet, we also continue to assess the capability and marketability of our existing rigs. Through this review, we made a decision in the first quarter to recycle the mid-water floater, the Transocean John Shaw, increasing our total rigs recycled or held for sale since the start of the downturn to 25. As we move through the year, we will continue this process and will remain decisive in determining the future of each rig as the market continues to evolve.
Before turning the call over to Mark and then Terry, I'd like to take a moment to talk at a high level about the market. As you well know, the near-term market outlook remains very challenging. At this point, we do not expect to see a meaningful recovery in rig activity before 2017 as customer budgets have been set for 2016 and are unlikely to improve until there's further recovery in the price of oil and confidence regarding its sustainability is bolstered. Even so, we remain very confident in the long-term fundamentals of offshore exploration and development and the drilling industry's inevitable recovery.
I visit with customers on a regular basis and my recent conversations with them have reinforced our position that future hydrocarbon supply requires significant production from offshore and more specifically from deepwater fields. Our largest customers have significant deepwater reserves and they recognize without increased activity, they will face production declines and reserve replacement challenges that will be difficult and costly to reverse and overcome.
North America, Venezuela, Mexico and the U.K. have all experienced year-over-year production declines, and we expect this will only increase as the recent deficiencies in reinvestment continue to impact overall supply. Additionally in my customer discussions, it's becoming more evident that they recognize the benefits of narrowing their supplier base for key services to a few select partners that can help them to deliver their operational and financial objectives. This market downturn has allowed them to cherry pick the highest quality contractors and service providers and move toward agreements that should promote direct negotiations on some of their prioritized opportunities.
Through both pricing concessions and a more collaborative approach between operators, contractors and service providers, the high cost previously associated with much of the deepwater activity are beginning to abate. The industry is now witnessing sustainable cost reductions that will ultimately drive economic development of large offshore projects well below previous price per barrel requirements.
As wells are drilled faster and more precisely and production equipment and facilities are engineered using more efficient approaches, the competitiveness of these assets will continue to improve. As oil prices then recover and the liquidity profile for our customers improves, we expect the offshore drilling activity declines we have experienced will reverse. When that time comes, we are confident that our stacked rigs are not only being preserved in the most cost-effective manner but in ways that will enable their swift reactivation and return to operation. Until that time, we will continue to prudently manage our balance sheet and cost structure while remaining intently focused on operations to ensure we remain the offshore industry's driller of choice.
I'll now turn the call over to Mark.

headline: Transocean Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jeremy, and good day to all. During today's call, I will recap the first quarter results, provide an update to our 2016 guidance and discuss our balance sheet and liquidity position.For the first quarter of 2016, we reported net income attrib
componenttext:
Thank you, Jeremy, and good day to all. During today's call, I will recap the first quarter results, provide an update to our 2016 guidance and discuss our balance sheet and liquidity position.
For the first quarter of 2016, we reported net income attributable to controlling interest of $249 million or $0.68 per diluted share. These results included $5 million or $0.01 per diluted share in net unfavorable items that are detailed in our press release. Excluding these items, adjusted net income was $254 million or $0.69 per diluted share.
Contract drilling revenue for the first quarter of 2016 decreased by $345 million sequentially to $1.1 billion. The decrease was primarily due to reduced activity associated with 634 fewer operating days during the quarter. Our operational and technical teams continued to perform at a very high level, delivering another quarter of 95% revenue efficiency. Other revenue decreased $165 million sequentially to $230 million during the quarter. This included $209 million in early contract termination fees primarily associated with the Discoverer Deep Seas and the Deepwater Millennium. When adjusting these early contract termination fees for contract drilling revenues expected during first quarter these rigs worked as planned, $133 million relate to days beyond March 31, 2016.
First quarter operating and maintenance expense was $655 million, down from $794 million in the prior quarter. The 16% decrease was largely due to lower activity, cost savings related to operational and restructuring initiatives and reduced stacking cost for our fifth- and sixth-gen DP floaters. This was partially offset by the $45 million of reactivation costs for the Henry Goodrich expensed during the quarter. The Goodrich begins its strategic contract with Husky later this month.
Additionally, we recognized $18 million of mobilization costs on the GSF Development Driller I that was previously anticipated to be recorded in the second quarter. Also, first quarter O&M expenses were negatively impacted by $3 million of restructuring costs associated with employee severances.
G&A expenses totaled $43 million, down $15 million from the prior quarter, which reflects our ongoing restructuring efforts. Our operating margin, including G&A expense, was approximately 47% for the quarter, driven higher by the impact of early contract terminations included in other revenue above.
The first quarter annual effective tax rate was 22.8% compared with 13.1% in the prior quarter. This increase was due to the lower adjusted pretax income and change in the mix of operating results from certain jurisdictions.
We ended the quarter with $2.6 billion in cash and cash equivalents, reflecting cash flow from operations for the first quarter of $631 million. This includes our working capital release of $128 million.
Capital expenditures for the first quarter totaled $368 million, largely associated with payments on the newbuilds. Since the last call, we opportunistically repurchased $100 million of debt at a cost of $84 million. As these debt repurchases were settled after the end of the quarter, the first quarter's balance sheet does not reflect these debt repurchases. Cash interest savings for these debt repurchases is approximately $23 million over the remaining term. This brings our total repurchases for the 3 quarters to $603 million at a cost of $557 million and an aggregate interest cost savings of approximately $105 million through maturity of this debt.
I will now provide an update on our financial expectations for 2016 and our liquidity expectations through 2017. Our 2016 revenue efficiency guidance remains at 95%. Other revenue for 2016 is expected to be between $260 million and $270 million. This includes customer reimbursables and the early contract termination fees recognized to date in 2016.
We expect full year operating and maintenance expense to raise between $2.1 billion and $2.3 billion. This 6% decrease from our previous guidance reflects reduced fleet activity, primarily as a result of early contract terminations. Consistent with activity, O&M cost will be higher in the first half of 2016 and trend lower toward the latter quarters as the number of rigs active decline during the year.
We estimate that O&M expense for the second quarter will be in the range of between $550 million and $570 million. We also expect the second half of the year to benefit from reduced stacking expenses and the beneficial cost impact resulting from a smaller, streamlined support organization.
Full year G&A expenses are expected to be approximately $160 million. Similar to O&M, this line is anticipated to decrease as we progress through the year. We estimate that the second quarter G&A will be approximately $45 million.
Full year 2016 net interest expense is expected to be between $360 million and $370 million. Net interest expense includes capitalized interest and interest income of $185 million and $10 million, respectively.
Full year 2016 annual effective tax rate is expected to be in the range between 28% and 30% as we expect higher tax rate for the remainder of the year. This is due to a significant reduction in net income from operations as fewer rigs are working and some have lower day rates.
There are no changes to our expected 2016 depreciation expense. Capital expenditures for the remainder of 2016 are expected to be approximately $1.1 billion, including approximately $1 billion for the newbuilds Deepwater Conqueror, Deepwater Pontus and Deepwater Poseidon. This amount includes capitalized interest. We expect maintenance CapEx to be approximately $80 million for the remainder of 2016.
Turning now to our financial position. Since our last call, we have enhanced our liquidity position by announcing 2 separate future newbuild delivery deferrals. In early March, we agreed with Keppel FELS to defer the delivery and related payments of our 5 high-specification jackups. This defers approximately $735 million from 2018 and 2019 into 2020.
In April, we amended the construction contracts with Jurong for the late delivery of 2 newbuild ultra-deepwater drillships by approximately 6 months each. These 2 proprietary Jurong Espadon III design drillships are now expected to be delivered in the first and third quarter of 2020. This defers approximately $420 million from 2019 into 2020.
We continue to evaluate the secured financing options in our 5 contracted newbuild drillships. As you're aware, these rigs are highly marketable assets due to the quality of our assets and their respective contracts as well as the contract duration. We'll provide a more fulsome update in due course.
We reiterate our assumptions related to our updated liquidity forecast through 2017. These include: Revenue efficiency of 95%, a limited number of new contract awards with day rates assumed to be at or near cash breakeven, a working capital release of approximately $500 million in total for the years 2016 and 2017. This includes the previously mentioned $128 million of release in the first quarter.
In 2017, we expect total CapEx of approximately $625 million. This includes $375 million in newbuild CapEx and $250 million for maintenance CapEx. Based on our current forecast, our projected liquidity at December 31, 2017, remains in the range of $4 billion to $5 billion. Our projection includes our $3 billion undrawn revolving credit facility that remains available to us through mid-2019.
To conclude, we are very pleased with our strong operational results, adequate liquidity and substantial contract backlog. We also believe the quality of our fleet, together with our propriety rig stacking methodology focused on efficient rig reactivation, better positions us to win more than our fair share of future drilling contracts, increasing our contract backlog and further bolstering our financial strength.
This concludes my prepared comments. I'll now turn the call over to Terry.

headline: Transocean Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mark, and good day to everyone. As you all know, the market remains very challenging. Despite the recent increase in oil prices from the multiyear lows experienced early in the year, operators remained hesitant to commit to long-term projects that
componenttext:
Thanks, Mark, and good day to everyone. As you all know, the market remains very challenging. Despite the recent increase in oil prices from the multiyear lows experienced early in the year, operators remained hesitant to commit to long-term projects that require significant levels of capital. However, as Jeremy mentioned, we continue to have meaningful dialogue with our customers, and they remain firmly committed to their deepwater assets as they view these as a necessary source of future reserves.
The real question is around the velocity with which these customers will ultimately add rigs in response to declines in reserve replacement and production. Even more so than in past cycles, our customers realize that the reduction in offshore drilling is not sustainable, especially considering the fact that the global demand for energy continues to increase.
In the meantime, as we await the eventual recovery, we will continue to position our fleet to take advantage of opportunities in the market. As stated in previous conference calls, our teams continue to battle for every opportunity in this highly competitive market, looking at ways we can best align with our customers' well plans and business objectives. This approach has once again proven to be successful as we signed several new contracts resulting in the addition of $138 million of contract backlog since the last earnings call, bringing our 2016 total to $184 million.
In our ultra-deepwater fleet, we extended the duration on the Deepwater Invictus by adding a 2-well contract at $350,000 a day in Trinidad, with additional bonus opportunity. This contract award highlights our stellar operational performance for BHP and our willingness to work with the customer to best meet their project priorities. We've also secured a 6-month contract on the KG2, returning her to work after being idled. While you are likely aware of the recent announcement from Hurricane Energy with respect to the Spitsbergen, we've waited to formally announce this contract pending approval of their board early this month. In India, we were awarded a 3-year contract on the mid-water floater, Actinia, also returning her to work after being idled. In total, our fleet and commercial strategy enabled us to return 3 idled rigs to our active fleet and to further extend work for another rig during the quarter.
As a result, our backlog as of April 21 is an industry leading $14.6 billion. This foundation provides solid future cash flow generation, with 79% of the revenues contracted with the super majors, 13% contracted with the independents and 8% contracted with the national oil companies. And further, we do not have contracts in our current backlog that permit cancellation for convenience without compensation.
Turning to the global market. While we are seeing some positive movement in the macro environment and improved confidence regarding oil prices for the second half of '16, we expect challenging conditions are likely to continue into '17, impacting both utilization and day rates. In order for contacting conditions to improve for next year's budgeting cycle, customers need to see these improved oil prices sustained in the coming months.
As the market stands today, ultra-deepwater marketed utilization is down to 79% with 32 rigs idle and 23 cold-stacked. Year-to-date, we've seen 11 fixtures that have been executed, mostly in Asia and India, in addition to a few in South America and Africa, with the majority being short-term work. Longer-term fixtures were largely agreed in '15 but executed in '16.
With the amount of rig availability in the market, including farmout opportunities, we'll continue to see strong competition for every opportunity. Another example of this increasing competition, as we understand it, is the recently announced Chevron Nigeria tender for 2 years, which drew numerous contractors.
As we wait for the award of the long-term exploration tender in India expected to be within the next 2 weeks, we understand the development work requiring 2 additional 1,500 meter DPs for almost 3 years' term per rig commencing in 2017, it is encouraging to see some customers are taking advantage of the lower pricing environment to proceed with their projects. Deepwater marketed utilization is down 71%. There have been 5 fixtures year-to-date, primarily in Asia and Europe. There are currently 11 idle and 10 cold-stacked deepwater units. While we await the result of the ongoing 600 meter tender in India, we're also happy to see another long-term tender about to come to the market. ONGC is expected to release the development tender for 1 more unit for almost 2-year term that will commence in '17.
Mid-water utilization is at 69% with 6 fixtures contracted year-to-date, mainly in India and Norway. Currently there are 16 mid-water rigs that are idle and 18 units cold-stacked. As previously stated, continued stability and improvement in commodity pricing will increase the number of opportunities for these assets in the U.K. and Norway.
Industry-wide, there are 151 cold-stacked floaters plus 53 units that are retired or being held for sale. We expect these numbers to increase with the relative high levels of supply and near-term lack of demand forcing the retirement of most assets.
The jackup market continues to deteriorate as a result of increased market oversupply. This is being exacerbated by very few rigs being scrapped due to minimal cost associated with cold-stacking and the growing supply of newbuild rigs being delivered. Marketed utilization is approximately 71%, with 120 rigs currently idle and 69 cold-stacked. There have been 21 fixtures year-to-date, mainly in the Middle East, Asia and U.K. Unlike the floater market, national oil companies are leveraging their local market dominance and lock contract terms in either renegotiating day rates or outright canceling the remaining term.
Overall, our customers remain focused on cost reduction, operational excellence and safe operations. And they remain committed to delivering their core business, which will undoubtedly include Deepwater exploration and development. Until we experience the uptick in demand for our assets and services, we will move forward with our strong liquidity, industry-leading backlog and excellent operational and safety performance as we continue to position Transocean to increase our market-leading position as we progress through the downturn.
This concludes my overview of the market, so I will turn it over to Brad.

headline: Transocean Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016

componenttext: Jeremy or, I guess, Terry can answer this question. So as we progressed through 2015, we started to see a pickup in contract terminations, not only for Transocean, but across the industry. And then it seems like it's accelerated again in early part of '16. Are we at a point now where generally customers that were going to cancel contracts are sort of have that behind them? Or is this something that we think is going to continue to sort of plague the industry over the next 6 to 12 months?

headline: Transocean Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Greg, good morning. I think that what we have to look at is from our own conversations with our customers, it's really hard for us -- difficult for us to project what will happen to our competitors. But for those folks that are suffering for the low
componenttext: Well, Greg, good morning. I think that what we have to look at is from our own conversations with our customers, it's really hard for us -- difficult for us to project what will happen to our competitors. But for those folks that are suffering for the lower commodity prices, I think we will see some more contract terminations or probably a little bit more contract renegotiation. But from our fleet, in our perspective, we are not hearing those conversations as of today. In fact, we are in conversations with some extensions of our fleet. So we believe that with our strong backlog, that our conversations, perhaps, are going to be a little bit different than our competitors.

headline: Transocean Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that's the point. Almost 80% of our backlog is with the super majors and 90% is with investment-grade companies. So we feel really good about the strength of the backlog and being able to convert that into future earnings and cash flow. Never
componenttext: Yes, I think that's the point. Almost 80% of our backlog is with the super majors and 90% is with investment-grade companies. So we feel really good about the strength of the backlog and being able to convert that into future earnings and cash flow. Never say never though. It depends on what happens in the market, obviously. But right now, the conversations -- we're not having those conversations with our customers.

headline: Transocean Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016

componenttext: Okay, great. And then Mark, just for you. I mean I saw that in April you brought back some debt. Any -- I'm just trying to sort of gauge why April, why not earlier this year? And then any color on which of the bonds were actually repurchased?

componenttext: Yes, sure, Greg. We focus mainly -- as I've mentioned to you guys in the past, focus mainly on the near-dated maturities. So we buy -- we have been buying back the '16, '17, '18s mainly with some focus on the '20s to '22s. It just so it worked out the previous quarter that our opportunity to actually attract bonds based upon availability was later in March.

componenttext: I guess my first question was I wanted to get your updated thoughts on the equity market as an option for your financial strategy, given the pretty strong support that Ensco got on theirs.

headline: Transocean Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, Ian. I think I've been very clear in the past that we have substantial liquidity. We have a industry-leading backlog and I think we have a debt maturity profile that allows us to avoid the equity market. I think we'll be opportunistic with r
componenttext: Good morning, Ian. I think I've been very clear in the past that we have substantial liquidity. We have a industry-leading backlog and I think we have a debt maturity profile that allows us to avoid the equity market. I think we'll be opportunistic with regard to adding and refinancing our maturities with secured debt options in the event that we're able to achieve that. But at this stage, we do not feel that equity is the right solution for Transocean.

headline: Transocean Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Very clear. I have a follow-up also for you, if you don't mind. I'm looking at your fifth-gen rigs that are stacked. It looks like 14 fifth-generation rigs that are mainly stacked, a couple of them idle or maybe almost stacked. Can you comment on the carr
componenttext: Very clear. I have a follow-up also for you, if you don't mind. I'm looking at your fifth-gen rigs that are stacked. It looks like 14 fifth-generation rigs that are mainly stacked, a couple of them idle or maybe almost stacked. Can you comment on the carrying value of those? And what your -- what the impairment test framework looks like for those rigs going forward? And weather we should think about a vulnerability there going forward?

headline: Transocean Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Ian, as you well know that the impairment test is based on the remaining life of the assets. And these assets were predominantly delivered around 2000. So you're looking at asset that would last through 2020. So given the fact that we have a signifi
componenttext: Well, Ian, as you well know that the impairment test is based on the remaining life of the assets. And these assets were predominantly delivered around 2000. So you're looking at asset that would last through 2020. So given the fact that we have a significant tail, on average about 15 years or so, of the remaining life of these assets, I think it's fair to say that we feel very strongly that given the way that we have approached our stacking on these assets, they have been cold-stacked with the intention of reactivating these rigs very quickly and cost-effectively. So as the market does recover in '18, '19, as Jeremy has mentioned in the past, we believe these rigs will come back to the market and would be able to earn sufficient cash flows to offset their carrying value over that remaining period.

componenttext: Yes, Angie, I think we've taken a pretty thoughtful view of the entire -- the global fleet and kind of positioned our rigs against that. As we look at our fifth-generation rigs, not all of them, but the vast majority of them, we see them being highly competitive when the market turns around. I mean other than really the Gulf of Mexico and pre-salt Brazil, these are excellent assets that have proven to be very valuable for us and our customers. So we feel good about our asset strategy and fifth-gens will be a part of that asset strategy.

componenttextpreview: Okay, okay. And then good to see that you're paying down some of the debt and I guess a little bit further looking out, going into late '16 and going into '17, if you don’t secure that secured financing on the Shell newbuilds, is it fair to assume that
componenttext: Okay, okay. And then good to see that you're paying down some of the debt and I guess a little bit further looking out, going into late '16 and going into '17, if you don’t secure that secured financing on the Shell newbuilds, is it fair to assume that cash is going to be drawn down or would you tap into the revolver? How are you thinking about cash versus your revolver on those debt maturities?

headline: Transocean Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Angie, we typically look at our liquidity as fungibles of cash and revolver. So we fully expect to be able to use a combination of both to retire the 2016s. The potential secured debt is opportunistic on our part. We don’t feel that its necessary to rai
componenttext: Angie, we typically look at our liquidity as fungibles of cash and revolver. So we fully expect to be able to use a combination of both to retire the 2016s. The potential secured debt is opportunistic on our part. We don’t feel that its necessary to raise that debt to retire the '16 or the '17s for that matter. So anything we get in addition to our current liquidity in a form of secured debt would be over and above what we have planned to manage through this cycle.

headline: Transocean Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016

headline: Transocean Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016

headline: Transocean Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, Ole, this is Mark. Look, I've been very clear that -- in the past on these calls, that currently the value arbitrage that we enjoy when we listed Transocean Partners for the first time has reversed. So it's not economic for us to be able to
componenttext: Good morning, Ole, this is Mark. Look, I've been very clear that -- in the past on these calls, that currently the value arbitrage that we enjoy when we listed Transocean Partners for the first time has reversed. So it's not economic for us to be able to use Transocean Partners in the capacity which was envisioned initially. That is still our intention if and when the market does recover for both the offshore drilling industry and for yield-based vehicles. So the intention there would be to nurture Transocean Partners as best we can and recognize, when the opportunity provides itself, we would utilize the vehicle and the capacity in which we intended.

headline: Transocean Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, very clear. A follow-up question would be your thoughts on Brazil. It strikes me that getting some of your international clients to become operators in pre-salt Brazil is probably the only thing that can bring the ultra-deepwater market back in bala
componenttext: Okay, very clear. A follow-up question would be your thoughts on Brazil. It strikes me that getting some of your international clients to become operators in pre-salt Brazil is probably the only thing that can bring the ultra-deepwater market back in balance again at any reasonable time frame. So have you had any thoughts? You have a very strong relationship, in particular, with one international client that recently made a very big bet on Brazil.

headline: Transocean Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's a good question. So we believe that the interest, certainly with the majors, is very high in Brazil. And we think that at some point, and of course I can't tell you when that time is going to happen, but the customers that are -- have that bet
componenttext: Yes, that's a good question. So we believe that the interest, certainly with the majors, is very high in Brazil. And we think that at some point, and of course I can't tell you when that time is going to happen, but the customers that are -- have that bet on Brazil are very focused on developing those opportunities. So when the time comes, I think we will be participating in a meaningful way. And again, I think as we wait for Petrobras to re -- take another look at their fleets and continue to high grade, I think that they're going to be able to extend some of these contracts and that we've been speaking with them a lot too. So again, we've been having a lot of conversations about Brazil.
